title: what r rate why important
story: THE R rate, also known as reproduction number, has been crucial to the governments understanding of the threat of coronavirus.Scientist and government officials have been using the R value to help them determine how to tackle the spread of Covd- and easing of lockdown measures.R, or R nought, refers to the average number of people that one infected person can expect to pass the coronavirus on to.Scientists use it to predict how far and how fast a disease will spread - and the number can also inform policy decisions about how to contain an outbreak.For example,a virus has an R of three, it means that every sick person will pass the disease on to three other peopleno containment measures are introduced.Its also worth pointing out that the R is a measure of how infectious a disease is, but not how deadly.Taking London as an example, with a current R value of . for coronavirus, it means that for every ten people who have the virus, it will be passed on to only four more people.The low R value means thateveryone continues lockdown and social distancing measures, London would theoretically be virus free by the end of May. The World Health Organisationestimated at the start of March that the coronavirus R stood somewhere between  and ..The UK is now generally below that because of the lockdown and the social distancing measures we have been doing over the past two months.In comparison, the seasonal flu is estimated to be roughly . while measles has a reproductive value of between  and .Despite this, these figures are not set in stone because a given pathogens R value changes with place and time.Jonathan Ball, professor of molecular virology at the University of Nottingham, told The : R is an indication of how much an infectious virus will spread in a population, and ious things impact that value.The susceptibility, size and density of the population that the infection is introduced into matters, as well as the infectiousness of the virus itself.Predictions of the R for Covid- are currently ied because no one knows exactly how many people have been infected in total.According to modelling published by Imperial College London, the R value stood somewhere between  and . in Europe before lockdowns came into effect.The most recent estimate of the nation-wide R-rate is said to be between . and .Below R is the important bit because it means the virus will likely peter out, but things are generally worse in the north of England to the point that the trend could reverse.New data released May  from Cambridge University suggests that in the North East and Yorkshire the R rate - the average number of people an infected person can pass the virus on to - is feared to be at around ..The South West has an R rate of ., slightly more than the North West which has a rate of ..Both the East of England and South East have a rate of ., followed by the Midlands with . and finally London with ..On May , , Boris Johnson urged the British public to help reduce the R value.In his address to the nation, he said: It depends on all of us – the entire country – to follow the advice, to observe social distancing, and to keep that R down.He added: We must make sure that any measures we take do not force the reproduction rate of the disease - the R - back up over one, so that we have the kind of exponential growth we were facing a few weeks ago.And to chart our progress and to avoid going back to square one, we are establishing a new Covid Alert System run by a new Joint Biosecurity Centre.And that Covid Alert Level will be determined primarily by R and the number of coronavirus cases.He continued: And in turn that Covid Alert Level will tell us how tough we have to be in our social distancing measures – the lower the level the fewer the measures.The higher the level, the tougher and stricter we will have to be.During one of the Downing Street press conferences, Sir Patrick Vallance revealed that it was highly likely there is an R value in the community of less than one.This means that every infected inidual passes the disease to less than one other person.This shows the lockdown has had a positive impact on the coronavirus outbreak as to bring an outbreak under control the R value needs to fall below one.However, when the number remains higher than one, the epidemic will grow. Sir Patrick admitted that the R value could be higher in some care homes and hospitals.He said: As I’ve said, it’s not true that the R is necessarily below one in every hospital or in every care home, and that’s the important area that we now need to look at and make sure that the appropriate measures are in place to try and reduce the R there.But it doesn’t change the overall view that I’ve described, that the R overall is below one and therefore we expect to see the slowing and the turn of the epidemic.There are lots of infection control measures experts can use to push this number down and reduce the spread.A study in the Lancet in April, for example, estimated that travel restrictions in Wuhan caused R to drop from . to . after just one week.Sir Patrick said that the draconian social distancing measures introduced in the UK have had a substantial impact so far.This is because as less people come into contact with one another, there is less chance for the virus to spread.He said on Thursday, April : The social distancing measures are needed to reduce the levels right down to a low level.At that point there may be decisions about which ones to relax and which ones not to relax.It’s important to keep the R below one, and this is all about trying to reduce contacts, particularly between households, reduce transmission and keep the levels low across the community.And Sir Patrick added that even small changes in the measures that are in place could lead to the R going above one.According to a pre-print study from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, the average number of people an inidual comes into contact with each day has dropped by  per cent since the UK’s lockdown began.“This would be sufficient to reduce R from a value from . before the lockdown to . during the lockdown, indicating that physical distancing interventions are effective,” the study, which tracked over , adults and has not yet been peer reviewed, concluded.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rich kind joe wicks inspiring mum
story: If he wasn’t already a household name before this began, Joe, with his spontaneous and generous offer of a daily free PE class, has certainly become one now.A whopping million people tuned in during the first week. He has stuck to his promise and shown up every day, despite having to have surgery on his wrist and being in evident pain at times.Not only that, but he is donating the revenue from advertising on the show to the NHS. He embodies the perfect combination of qualities required to be a good business person: Do all you can, give something back and be ethical.In the past six weeks he has made more than £.million as new fans snapped up his -Day Plan well-being programme from his Body Coach site.But I really don’t think this was about making more money or becoming more famous.Bear in mind that Joe, who is only , has already made millions following the success of his cookbook and his online fitness classes.He really didn’t need to make more money or be more famous.I honestly believe he just wants children everywhere to experience the joy of fitness.There is a lot to like about Joe. But one thing I love about him is that one of his first le goals was to buy his mum, Raquela, a house. Having grown up on a council estate in Surrey, with Raquela and brothers Nikki and George, Joe always dreamed of being able to spend his earnings on his mum after she supported him in the earliest days of his career.“My mum’s always lived in a council house. We’ve never had mortgages. It wasn’t on the radar for us.“So when I could take that money I earned from that book and say ‘Mum, I’m buying your house. It’s yours’, that was an amazing moment for me.”Joe didn’t have an easy childhood. He has spoken about his father Gary still struggling with heroin addiction. But rather than repeating history, he actively decided to take a dferent path.He found exercise as a coping method. “I used exercise probably as a way to manage my feelings,” he has said.He said: “Because of my dad’s addiction, and the damage I saw it cause, me and Nikki steered clear of it. We weren’t smoking weed. We were training, exercising and playing sport. Along the line, I decided that wasn’t going to be my destiny.”Things in le either crush you or make you the person you were always meant to be. The strength of character it takes to turn your back on the path chosen by your first and most important role model — your dad — is immense.It would be so easy for him to have chosen the same path as his father or use his father’s addiction as an excuse for not making the most of his le.Joe has said he tries not to dwell on his past nor judge his dad. All that matters to him now is being happy and looking forward.The moral of this story is: Put the graft in, keep pushing yourself and never give up.But one of the many likeable things about Joe is how readily he credits Raquela for her role in his success, saying she taught them “right and wrong”, while his dad was “in and out of rehab”.She must be a hell of a woman to have brought up three boys so well. Joe and Nikki work together now, which is testament to the strength of their family ties.Knowing all this about Joe makes it all the more amazing he found his happy ever after when he married his model we Rosie in , and the pair now have two adorable children — Indie who’s  months and four-month-old Marley.It would be easy to resent his success. But how could anyone wish Joe anything other than happiness, given what he has overcome and also his approach to le I’m as keen as the next person for the lockdown to end and for normal le to resume – at least as much as it possibly can.But when I read about the fliers advertising mass gatherings, promising picnics and live music in cities across the UK this weekend, I couldn’t believe my eyes.At least eight events were being organised by anti-vaxxing group UK Freedom Movement, which claims the lockdown is illegal.Its posters headlined “UK Mass Gathering” said: “We say no to the coronavirus bill, no to mandatory vaccines, no to the new normal and no to the unlawful lockdown.”It is also urged people to gather in a major park in the eight locations, including London, Sheffield and Edinburgh, to “bring a picnic, some music and let’s have some fun and say yes to le”.Yes, lockdown measures are extreme and yes, we all want them to relax and for normality to .But what the organisers of this are failing to realise is that you can’t protest or demonstrate against a virus.And while there is so much still left for us to understand about how this particular virus works, to attend a mass gathering in protest seems like a fool’s errand.This event is clearly organised by idiots, for idiots.If only we’d all been quick-witted enough to self-isolate with someone who knows how to do our hair, like Kate Moss, who has been hunkering down with A-lister stylist James Brown.That said, Kate is an absolute beauty and clearly a supermodel, whether she is having a good hair day or a bad one.As luck would have it I am currently living with my mum.She has done a grand job dyeing my roots so far, but I think a blow-dry may be beyond her remit.Luckily, with a pandemic going on, and staff to worry about, I have more important things to think about than my hair.Twitter has been among the first companies to announce that it will not be bringing employees back into the workplacethey would prefer to work from home.And for more and more people, home is likely to be the new workplace – with meetings taking place on screens.The past few weeks have shown us that as long as people have a laptop and wi-fi, many can work from home.For lots of us, being allowed to do so means we save loads of money on travel and hundreds of hours of commuting time, while massively reducing our carbon footprint.And we’ll never have to buy a stale sandwich again.Meanwhile, companies will save a fortune on rent.All in all, this new way of working, for those who can do it, makes sense.Over the past few weeks we have all become much more aware of people’s proximity to us.And yes, with streets that have fewer cars than ever before, no doubt some of us are stepping into the road to avoid another pedestrian who could come within two metres of us.But police have felt the need to issue warnings to pedestrians not to walk into the road to dodge fellow pedestrians because it is dangerous .Seriously, is such a warning really necessary I know we have all been in lockdown for a while but surely we haven’t taken leave of our common sense and will remember to look left and right when we cross the road . . . won’t we It’s now been eight weeks since our Thursday night Clap For Carers began. And looking at this photo of Boris Johnson outside No from Thursday, it’s a good reminder that things are changing all the time.When you compare it to the picture taken of him just days before he was admitted to hospital it really shows the big dference a few weeks make.He looks more or less back to his old self. Also, it’s really cheering to see new mum Carrie looking so well and so happy.We seem to be seeing lots of people in their swim-wear at the moment, with not a. pool in sight!Normally I try to give thanks for my strong and able body rather than worrying too much about what it looks like.But it’s hard not to feel a tad wistful looking at photos of Kimberley Garner, who looks so fit and gorgeous she’d no doubt be awarded swimwear body of the week,such an award existed. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: get businesses open coronavirus
story: As the chief of the OBR made crystal-clear yesterday, the scarring will be permanent unless society can be ed to some semblance of normality as soon as is safely possible.Which means serious thought must now be given to getting businesses open:that involves masks in workplaces and Perspex separations in cafes and bars, so be it. It might feel strange at first, but we’ll get used to it.Militant unions telling teachers they should refuse to go back to work must also urgently rethink their stance.Reopening schools is obviously essentialwe are to prevent the poorest and most vulnerable children falling behind — new research reveals that better-off children are spending a whopping  per cent more time each day on education than those from poorer homes.But as parents can only go back to work once their kids are in class, it’s also the only way to kickstart the economy.Of course, there will always be an element of risk to getting society up and running again. Even before coronavirus, it would have been impossible for anyone to guarantee the safety of every worker every day.But the Government has stressed it’s “extremely unlikely” a school could be the source of a Covid- outbreak.And given the risks frontliners take every single day, that assurance should be good enough for teaching unions.WE welcome the news that the Government plans to push ahead with legislation to end free movement and replace it with a points-based immigration system before the end of this year.The new system is exactly what Brexit-voting Sun readers wanted: it will let us welcome the brightest and best — including doctors, nurses and carers — to the UK based on what they have to offer, not where they come from.And it’s logical to get it introduced quickly so businesses have time to prepare before the transition period ends.Let’s hope MPs have the sense to back the bill.WE can all sleep a little more soundly in our beds now the Government looks set to hit its target of recruiting , contact-tracers by the end of next week.It’s been obvious for a long time that widespread testing and tracing is the best way to contain the virus: all the countries that have fared best have been doing it from the start.But thanks to dodgy advice from Public Health England, Boris and his ministers gave up on it back in March.What a relief they’ve finally seen the light.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Although some restrictions have since been eased following a review, other directives such as the closure of schools and non-essential shops are still subject to further updates from the government.According to the law which brought about the lockdown, the Government must review restriction measures every three weeks.The last review was on May , with Boris Johnson making changes on May .This means the next review could be held in the week beginning May .The Governments next review is expected to clary the status on a number of restrictions put in place as a result of the coronavirus lockdown.Brits will be expecting to learn whether restrictions will be relaxed and how the country is being led to a level of normality.Among the measures which could be given further clarity after the next review are: Following the Prime Minister, Boris Johnsons speech on the lockdown rules on May , things were slightly eased in England.People are still urged to work from home for the foreseeable future, however those who cannot do so are allowed to travel to worktheir workplaces are open.These include people who work in the food production industry, construction workers and those who partake in scientic research.This rule does not apply to hospitality workers employed in cinemas, pubs and restaurants. They must remain shut until a later date.Public transport must be avoided, according to the new lockdown rules, although reports have shown packed buses and trains in parts of the country.Brits are now allowed to meet people who are not members of their household, providing they follow social distancing guidelines.Funerals are still allowed to go ahead with a limited amount of attendees, of immediate family members.The rules on exercising have also been changed with people now able to take unlimited outdoor exercise.With the approach of summer, people are also now able to go to the park to sunbathe and must follow social distancing measures. The Government announced the lockdown on March .In an unprecedented move, Brits were ordered to stay at home with the exception of key workers, while non-essential shops and facilities such as restaurants, gyms and pubs were instructed to shut.Schools were also closed as a result of the lockdown rules.The restrictions were due to last for three works but were extended following review and advice from ious communities and departments.Lockdown measures are expected to last into June and may go beyond that, following guidelines by the government.Social distancing rules are however, expected to be in place beyond that.Mr Johnson has indicated that he wants the UK to resume near normality by July.He has said this would depend on whether the public abides by the new lockdown rules.Measures are currently being eased in phases with the final steps being the reopening of non-essential businesses.The earliest these final steps will be taken is July , according to the Governments -page action plan for leading the country to a new normal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: THE infamous R rate is currently guiding the Governments coronavirus response, as each of the planned phases depend on how infectious Covid- is. The rate has emerged during several Downing Street briefings, with both officials and the Prime Minister.Dferent parts of the UK have a dferent R infection rate - which is used to indicate the speed the virus is spreading.According to experts from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, the East Midlands has the fastest spread of infection with a rate of between . and ..London, which has been the hardest hit in the country has a R rate of . to . — the lowest in the country.Herefordshire, Norfolk, Durham and Cumberland have  times as many cases as Devon, Cornwall and Dorset.While this is dficult to measure, a number of reasons could come into play here, among them the fact the R rate will tend to be higher in places with higher population densities, like large cities such as London.Certain places which saw a large number of coronavirus cases may now also have a large number of people with immunity to the virus, while cities will also tend to have more care homes and hospitals which will affect the numbers.There are also dferences in how people live together, with people usually living in bigger family groups outside the large cities.Similarly, places with higher levels of deprivation and poverty will affect the R rate as well.Public Health England together with researchers at the University of Cambridge are working to regularly nowcast and forecast Covid- infections and deaths. This is real-time tracking of the pandemic, as data accumulate over time, and is an essential component of a public health response to a new outbreak.Click here to see the latest R rate in your area. The so-called R number is now between . and . — it needs to be kept below one.Below R is the important bit because it means the virus will likely peter out.The R rate needs to be below  for the UK to move out of lockdown.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ally ross live dutch eurovision tribute
story: Wimbledon  Couldn’t care less.Glastonbury  I was genuinely thrilled to hear the environment would be getting a break from all those thousands of marauding BBC staffers.But Eurovision  That one stopped me in my tracks with a “say it ain’t so ” when I heard it was cancelled.It’s nearly always my favourite TV event of the year and the BBC’s most entertaining live broadcast by some distance.Disappointment turned to hope, however, when I learned the BBC was going to fill several blank hours with a night of Eurovision programmes.A four-pronged assault,you include Rylan’s A to Z, on BBC, that began badly with a Pointless special and a top  rundown of songs on Eurovision: Come Together, where the only new thing we learned was that Britain’s  entrant, James Newman, looks “a bit Fred West” after two months of lockdown.The night’s success or failure, though, was always going to hinge on a hastily arranged live broadcast from the Netherlands called Eurovision: Europe Shine A Light, in honour of Katrina And The Waves, which had me in the palm of its hand from the moment Graham Norton introduced it as “well meaning”.He did not lie.It was as well meaning as hell, with three very earnest Dutch hosts plus Norton, on his usual voiceover duties, introducing a -second burst of all  entries, followed by the artists’ thoughts and reflections on the global coronavirus pandemic, which were everything and anything you wanted them to be.Some were sweet and to the point, like Azerbaijan’s Efendi: “Stay hellzy!”Others were easy to misinterpret, like Moldova’s Natalia Gordienko: “A penis is wad surrounds you.”And Austria’s Vincent Bueno was just a self-serving berk: “At this time we should listen to a lot of music. Especially my track, Alive.”The music didn’t disappoint, either, ranging all the way from the excellent Icelandic entry, Think Of Things, to knock-kneed techno from some Russian live-wires called Little Big.My personal highlight, though, was the nutty Latvian bird, Samanta Tina, who turned up for her promotional video wearing a PPE mask and squirting a bottle of disinfectant everywhere.If ever it got a bit too “Eurovision”, though, there was a special guest on hand to calm the mood down.Sweden’s Mans Zelmerlow sang Heroes in his back garden , Italy’s Diodato slowly murdered Volare in a CGI amphitheatre and Ireland’s Johnny Logan had either aged quite dramatically or had to be replaced, right at the last second, by Julian Assange on the poignant What’s Another Year.The one constant, though, was Norton, who handled Eurovision’s new socially-distanced, time-delayed, non-competitive format as brilliantly as he did the old one and was in no mood to spare feelings.“Samanta Tina. She’s tried to represent Latvia six times, Lithuania twice and now she’s got through it’s been cancelled. You’d think she’d take the hint, wouldn’t you.”“Serbia’s answer to The Pussycat Dolls, when the question is — name a group that isn’t as good as The Pussycat Dolls ”It was a joy to watch after seeing so many hosts and shows fail spectacularly with “the new normal” and my only real complaint was that there wasn’t enough of him or the event.I wanted a vote as well, of course. But by the time I was ready for Norton to annihilate the regional juries, it was all over.Lesson learned, though. If I ever take this event for granted or complain about the running time again, you have permission to shoot me down in righteous flames.Meantime, stay hellzy.The Real Marigold Hotel, Britt Ekland: “I look in the mirror — it’s OK. I’m not going to scare the children.”Channel  continuity introducing The Last Leg: Locked Down Under: “Two comedy geniuses coming right up here, Aisling Bea and Kevin Bridges.” So, one comedy genius then. And Aisling Bea.BACK in southern India, on BBC’s hugely enjoyable series The Real Marigold Hotel, Duncan Bannatyne has just bottled the eight-hour overnight train journey to Madurai.It could’ve been the heat, it could’ve been the food and a dodgy stomach.Or it could’ve been the fact Britt Ekland is all over him like a cheap sari, no matter how many times the multi-millionaire businessman mentions his “young we”.A woman who will not be denied, Britt needs male validation and constant reassurance.So, during one of the brief moments she wasn’t pestering Duncan to within an inch of his le, Britt visited a vedic astrologer, in downtown Puducherry, and hit him with this loaded question. “Am I going to have work ”Work  Are you ever, Britt. “The sun is in the constellation of Hasta,” apparently.So I’d expect work on your face, work on your eyelids, work on your rear end. A work frenzy, in fact.As for actual employment, though I think we can safely say Venus’s transit is currently “resting’ and her earth signs will be “aspecting”, until the panto equinox. So I’d go with Plan A Duncan.Yet when Miriam Margolyes told The Last Leg she wanted Boris Johnson to die from coronavirus they said nothing.So do you think this is because A Equity’s learned its lesson about rushing to judgment  Or B The thought she’d said something wrong never entered their thick, hypocritical luvvie heads No need to reply.Danny Murphy: “Spurs have always been consistently inconsistent.”Joe Root: “We have to make sure players don’t get ill, or even unwell.”WORST TV show of the lockdown  I’ll hear your pleas on behalf of Have I Got News For You, Gemma Collins: Diva On Lockdown, The Mash Report, The Steph Show and Mo Gilligan, whose All Star Happy Hour on Channel  makes Rob  Romesh look like Abbott  Costello.But they can, I suppose, all use technology as an excuse. Only stupidity and a tin ear for the public mood can explain my own choice for that title.It’s BBC’s credit card roulette series I’ll Get This, which concluded last week with Fleur East, Johnny Vegas, Mike Tindall, John Barnes and Sue Perkins taking part in a series of minor challenges and guessing games, in a roped-off area of a London restaurant, to settle a £ dinner bill.Not the sort of guessing games that might have engaged viewers, like “guess the appearance fee” or “guess how many TV presenters would have to die before Sue got another stab at hosting the Baftas”, but a game of “Guess the weight of the waiter”.A task more suited to the Bullingdon Club, you’d imagine, but this lot prodded him, lted him and generally talked about him like he was invisible.“I can squat it.” “Oh God, he’s big boned.”Having established, beyond reasonable doubt, there was almost nothing the five celebrities wouldn’t do to get on television, it was the response to the next question – “Do you like or dislike being famous ” – that sealed its place in lockdown hell for me.Unanimously they went for the latter, not with any self-awareness or sarcasm, but with a genuine sense of hurt that anyone could think otherwise and former Celebrity Big Brother contestant Sue Perkins apparently speaking for them all when she very solemnly replied: “I love my job, I dislike being famous.”Some job, Sue. Some bloody job.THIS week’s winner is ABC’s Martin Fry and Kate Green MP, as seen in C’s excellent The Truth About Traveller Crime.Sent in by Francis Harvey. Picture research Alfie Snelling.HARDBALL, Ore Oduba: “An Irish stew is traditionally made using which meat ”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “The young of what flying mammals are called pups ”Jim: “Seals.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which famous British vet wrote If Only They Could Talk and It Shouldn’t Happen to a Vet ”.Davie Robertson describing a bout of Himalayan altitude sickness on BBC Scotland’s wonderful Return To Real Kashmir FC docu- mentary: “The worst day of my le, and I’ve played at Albion Rovers.” Jeremy Clarkson turning out to be a better Millionaire host than Chris Tarrant.And an -year-old patient called Peter, who was saved from the Holocaust as a small child, winning his battle for le, against all odds, on BBC’s Hospital Special: Fighting Covid- – an astonishing two-part series that was a privilege to watch.THIS Morning’s Phillip Schofield attempting to jump on board Piers Morgan’s Covid outrage bandwagon.The terrying news Shirley Carter and the rest of the EastEnders cast will be “doing their own hair and make-up from now on”, as I’d assumed they already did.White Lines turning out to be just another load of over-hyped Netflix rubbish.And Antiviral Wipe host Charlie Brooker becoming the latest in a long line of TV presenters to exclude men from his list of groups at more risk of dying from coronavirus.Because even though we’re  to  per cent more likely to die than women, in every country, it’s box-ticking political correctness that drives the BBC’s news coverage, not basic compassion and humanity. title: teachers unions science re open schools
story: You’d think they would be keener than anyone to heed the science.But when Government experts or even the WHO contradict their desire to keep schools shut, they ignore it.Or they wheel out the BMA — asit represented medical opinion, rather than just being another left-wing trade union.Their latest wheeze, part of an absurd dossier of  demands, is to refuse to mark homework in case members catch Covid from a book.The risk is minuscule . . . nil,they take precautions.Most primary kids the Government wants toon June  get minimal homework anyway.And, as Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jonathan Van-Tam says, they neither catch the disease severely nor pass it on like they do flu.It is impossible to ensure that teachers will be  per cent safe before they— as it is for any worker.There WILL be a statistically tiny threat as long as this disease persists. Le is full of them. This is another.Unions cannot demand an exemption.This protracted shutdown is already doing immense damage to pupils, especially the most disadvantaged.The truth is the unions are capitalising on a mainly middle-class reluctance toto work because many have lost perspective about the real risk.In fairness, that reflects the success of the Government’s “stay home” campaign.But now deaths and infections are falling steadily and the economy is in dire trouble we must sht gear.Publishing daily figures of Covid recoveries will help.Not least because the total will be in the millions, as opposed to the death toll of ,.Awful though that latter figure is, it remains a small fraction of the overall.So does the recent estimate of those now infected: some , in England, of a population of ,,.Only one in  has Covid, in some areas far less.The fact we can now test everyone with symptoms, and have , contact tracers, should drive even those figures down.Teachers, meantime, should ponder whether their unions have lost the plot.WE welcome Prince Charles’s call for anyone currently furloughed to help rescue our farmers by picking vital fruit and veg.We welcome, too, that you’ll get paid on top of your bailout cash. today — and help feed Britain through our worst crisis since the war.IF fruit picking isn’t your bag, you can do your bit for public health just by sunbathing.Lack of vitamin D is linked to the more severe coronavirus bouts.And you can top that up by exposure to sunshine in what looks like being a glorious week.We’ve always said The Sun’s good for you.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mansion for sale troy house monmouthshire 33 bedrooms
story: Troy House in Monmouthshire originates from the th century and comes with its own chapel, but the auctioneers have warned it needs “extensive” work to make it habitable.It was originally built for the family of the Duke of Beaufort and comes with six acres set in beautul countryside along with two tennis courts.But after having been previously used as a school and a hostel the , sq ft property has seen better days.Auctioneers Allsop warn: “Presented in poor condition and requiring extensive works of modernisation and refurbishment.”It adds: “The property may afford possible potential for redevelopment and or a number of alternative uses, subject to obtaining all necessary consents.”These photos show just how much work needs doing after years of neglect.The oldest part of the house dates back to the s when it was built by Henry Somerset and is said to have hosted Henry VII for five days in August .The current house was built in the th century.During its more recent history it was owned by an order of French Catholic nuns who used it as a convent and girls’ school.It has also been used as a school for boys.Richard Adamson, Partner and Auctioneer at Allsop said: “Troy House has received a signicant amount of interest with over  enquiries regarding the property, in just over a week of coming to the market.“We have seen a mixed-bag of interest from people who could use the property for multiple uses including as a private home, converting into a boutique hotel and spa or refurbished into luxury apartments, subject to planning.“The property has a committed seller who is happy for the house to be sold at true value - as a result, we anticipate some competitive bidding on auction day.”The property is due to be put up for auction on May  with bidding taking place online due to the coronavirus restrictions.

title: dad pushing toddler balcony swing
story: The heart-stopping video shows the man repeatedly pushing child believed to be his daughter, on the balcony of their Puerto Rico apartment.In the  second clip, the child flies high up into the air and nearly up to the balcony above the apartment.Despite the balcony being on the eighth floor, the toddler doesn’t appear to be secured with any safety equipment.The video was captured by Jonathan Padilla, a journalist for the Mexican Herald, and was widely shared on Reddit.A man swung his underage daughter on the balcony of his apartment during this quarantine,” he said.Those who saw the video slammed the man for risking his childs le.Just because you cannot go to the park does not mean you can risk your childs le, said oneOthers pointed out the dad could have installed the swing inside the flat.All you need is an over the door pull up bar, and this swing could be inside the apartment.Some said the child could easily have slipped off the swing and fallen off the building .They have swings that go on door jams and that you can mount in the door frame. title: rishi sunak severe coronavirus recession
story: CHANCELLOR Rishi Sunak has warned the UK is facing a severe recession, the likes of which the nation has never seen before.He told MPs today the Government would not be able to save every job and there could be a long-term scarring of the British economy.He said: I certainly wont be able to protect every job and every business, were already seeing in the data there will be more hardship to come.Lockdown is having a signicant impact on our economy and we are likely to face a severe recession the likes of which we havent seen .Of course that will have an impact on employment.Mr Sunak said theand depth of that recession will depend on how much longer the nation is forced to stay in economic shutdown to keep coronavirus from ripping through the UK.He said: The question that occupies my mind and long term is more relevant is to what degree of long term scarring is there on the economy as the result of this recession The number of people claiming unemployment benefits has soared to . million, rising by , in April compared to March, and the number of people relying on the Governments furlough and self-employment schemes has hit  million.It was revealed this morning unemployment in the UK had skyrocketed by , to . million in three months to March.She said: “It’s a struggle month on month on my salary, so this has hit me hard.It couldn’t have come at a worse time.”Mr Sunak said: The question iswhat do weto  The jury is out.We are clearly dealing with something unprecedented, so the longer the depth of the recession it is likely the degree of that scarring will be greater.National economic growth slumped by a massive . per cent in just March alone - before the country had even experience a full month in lockdown.The collapse is the largest ever monthly slump on record.The Treasury predicted last week the pandemic will cost the exchequer £billion this year. The Office of Budget Responsibilityhas also warned that the nation will have to borrow £ billion just this year to buoy up the Governments support schemes.Mr Sunak said the cost of both the employee furlough and self employed schemes would cost several tens of billions of pounds by the time those schemes are wound down.Mr Llewellyn, of Darlington, Co Durham, said: “I am due a payment from the Government but it hasn’t arrived yet.It has been horrible not being able to work, it is all I’ve ever known.”The Chancellor announced last week that the furlough scheme - which pays employees  per cent of their pay up to £, a month - would be extended to October.He said today: This is unprecedented action, clearly, I genuinely believe that the situation would be considerably worse long term had we not taken this action.We will have increased debt as a result of this year, but medium term what will matter is what is the size of our economy To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: school delayed opening north
story: More local authorities yesterday advised their schools to stay closed on that date, including the first Tory-run council.It also emerged the NEU teaching union boss has threatened to wage a social media campaign against heads who defy their orders.Conservative-controlled Solihull in the West Midlands said yesterday classrooms must be made safe and may not be ready until June .Leeds City Council said a June  reopening would be “impossible” while Sefton Council in Merseyside urged schools to close until June .Calderdale Council in West Yorks said it will defy the Government, saying: “We cannot advise our local schools it will be safe to reopen yet.”They were joined by a string of other local authorities in the North, including Bury, Hartlepool and Blackburn and Darwen.However Tory MPs in Bury laid into the Labour-run council over the revolt. James Daly and Christian Wakeford urged headteachers to ignore the “political grandstanding” and make their own call.Meanwhile, NEU boss Kevin Courtney has promised to target heads who reopen without sticking to his enormous -page health and safety checklist.It includes a whopping  questions and calls for extra cleaners to wash paint brushes.He told activists in a video call: “We will be talking with our regional secretaries about putting things on social media, saying this school is putting lives at risk.“And we will be threatening heads with thatthey are behaving in those bad ways.”Education Secretary Gavin Williamson met union bosses yesterday in a bid to talk them round.The Government has set out five strict tests — including getting death and infection rates down — before schools can reopen for kids in reception, year one and six.The PM’s spokesman stressed it was only “possible” pupils will go back on June , adding: “That will only happenit’s safe to do so.”Labour’s Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham backed the growing council revolt.He said: “There needs to be a little flexibility offered to councils like Bury to put in place the local arrangements to reassure parents, teachers and the wider community.”He added: “If that means a week or a couple of weeks beyond June , I say so be it.”The Government’s senior scientist Angela McLean said the Sage group will assess tomorrowkids can head back on June .Environment Secretary George Eustice said schools must reopen as we start to “live alongside this virus for some time to come”.An NEU spokesman said  school staff in Britain have died from the virus, adding: “It is our duty to protect our members and keep them safe at work during this awful pandemic.”By Kate DochertyKIDS are sending a big “thank you” to their heroic teachers.Pupils posted videos and snaps on social media to mark Thank a Teacher Day today.Grace, , from St Albans, Herts, penned a poem. title: coronavirus epicentre latin america latest
story: The region is now the new epicentre of the coronavirus pandemic with authorities finding bodies in the streets as they struggle to enforce lockdown restrictions.Brazil remains the worst-hit country in Latin America and has the third largest number of infections in the world at more than ,.More than  percent of intensive care beds are full in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo.There are now fears that Latin Americas street markets may have helped spread the killer bug.In Lima, four out of five merchants in the citys major fruit market have tested positive for Covid- while spot tests at five other markets show at least half the workers had the disease.Cops and the military are now carrying out testing at markets after Peru’s president Martín Vizcarra refused to shut down the wholesalers.In the capital, patients took up  per cent of ICU beds as of Friday. The country has the worlds th-highest number of confirmed cases, with more than ,.Infections are also increasing in poor areas of Buenos Aires, the capital of Argentina, where authorities relaxed strict lockdown measures last week, allowing some businesses to open and children to walk outside on weekends.Slums in the city account for  per cent of Covid- cases while the country as a whole has over , infected and a death toll of , official figures show.In Chiles capital Santiago, more than  per cent of intensive care beds were full last week.The citys main cemetery dug , emergency graves to prepare for a wave of deaths.In Colombias Amazon region, cases have shot up in recent weeks, from  at the start of the month to , on Monday.The infections are concentrated in Leticia, a city on the Amazon river that borders both Brazil and Peru.Locals believe its related to the increase in cases in Brazils Amazon.Pictures have emerged of indigenous tribes in the Brazilian state of Amazonas collecting medicinal plants to treat the symptoms of the coronavirus.The indigenous tribes in the region have refused medical help from authorities and prefer to rely on their own ancestral remedies.In Mexico, intensive care occupancy is below  percent in most cities, although deaths have begun to overwhelm funeral homes and crematoriums in the Mexico City borough of Iztapalapa.More than , people have died in the country while over , have tested positive.Covid- is sickening thousands in the Ecuadorian capital of Quito, where  per cent of intensive care beds were occupied as of Friday.“In terms of intensive care, were stripped bare, the citys health secretary Len Mantilla said.But why are cities in the region struggling to cope with the pandemic Some doctors say patients are dying because of a lack of ventilators or because they couldnt get to a hospital fast enough.With intensive care units swamped, officials plan to move patients from capitals like Lima and Santiago to hospitals in smaller cities that arent as busy – a move which risks spreading the disease further.Latin American countries halted international flights and rolled out social distancing guidelines around the same time as the US and Europe, delaying the arrival of large-scale infection, said Dr. Marcos Espinal, of the Pan American Health Organisation.“Latin America was the last wave”, said Dr Espinal, who previously worked at the World Health Organisation.He warned that authorities need to maintain anti-virus restrictions even as the US and Europe reopen.Some of the hardest-hit cities, like Lima and Santiago, imposed strict, early lockdowns - but officials have struggled to enforce them as the poor need to work to feed their families while the wealthy are used to flouting regulations.Latin America is the worlds most unequal region, a reality that Dr Espinal said made it dficult to balance health and economic growth, with millions facing increased poverty during title: sitting 6ft apart may be too closes
story: SITTING ft apart in the park could still spread coronavirus, a new study has found. According to researchers at the University of Nicosia in Cyprus, light winds can blow Covid- droplets as far as ft in five seconds - raising questions around the Governments m rule.Boris Johnson announced last week that Brits can meet up with one other person from another household outdoors - as long as they keep m apart.However researchers at the University of Nicosia in Cyprus, say their findings suggest safety distance guidelines may not be doing enough to prevent the spread of Covid-.For the study, published in the journal Physics of Fluid, the team looked at how saliva travels through the air.They created a computer simulation that looks at how every saliva droplet, large and small, moves through the air after a person coughs.Just one single cough lets out around , droplets, with many of them dispersing in dferent directions.From a sneeze, as many as , droplets might be let out.Dr Talib Dbouk, a senior researcher at the Defense and Security Research Institute at the University of Nicosia said: Each cell holds information about iables like pressure, fluid velocity, temperature, droplet mass, droplet position, etc.The purpose of the mathematical modelling and simulation is to take into account all the real coupling or interaction mechanisms that may take place between the main bulk fluid flow and the saliva droplets, and between the saliva droplets themselves.Results showed that even in the slightest breeze of mph , saliva can travel ft in five seconds.Dr Dimitris Draikakis, a professor in the Medical School and the School of Sciences and Engineering at the University of Nicosia, said: The droplet cloud will affect both adults and children of dferent heights.Shorter adults and children could be at higher riskthey are located within the trajectory of the travelling saliva droplets.This work is vital, because it concerns health and safety distance guidelines, advances the understanding of spreading and transmission of airborne diseases, and helps form precautionary measures based on scientic results.The findings come after the UKs former Conservative Party leader Iain Duncan Smith called for the Prime Minister to consider lowering the two-meter rule to get the economy moving today.But the Government has consistently stuck to its advice, despite previous findings. Back in April, Chinese scientists discovered people with coronavirus could spread the bug to others from ft away.They found virus-laden aerosols were mainly concentrated near and downstream from patients at up to  feet, though smaller quantities were found upstream at up to eight feet.Today, the Government announced the number of coronavirus cases in the UK is nearing ,, after , more infections were confirmed today.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.

title: blackpool liverpool hull unemployment coronavirus

title: uk schools reopen june government lockdown plan
story: Justice Secretary Robert Buckland today revealed he was not expecting everyone to be back by then, with at least  councils expressing concern about the Government plans.Officials have instructed schools to get ready for reception, year one and six to  from the start of June,its safe to still do so.They have issued advice on how to make sure classrooms and playgrounds are as secure as possible - including maximum class sizes of  and keeping desks further apart.However, the plans have sparked a fierce backlash with unions warning teachers not to go, and now councils all over Britain saying they wont sanctions schools who dont reopen.Among those against the plans are Birmingham, Calderdale council in Yorkshire, and Conservative-controlled Solihull.More councils are expected to join in rejecting the plans today.This morning Mr Buckland insisted the government is still working towards a June  date, but admitted it was not looking good.He said: Im not going to sit here and pretend that suddenly on June  everything will be unorm.We always said the st of June was conditional, not just on the R-rate but the need to make places of work safe.I am hearing what’s being said by our union representatives and brilliant teachers.We have to accept the fact that councils are employers and decisions have to be made collectively.BradfordLeedsWakefieldCalderdaleRochdaleSolihillBirminghamStockportWirralLiverpoolWiganSloughEssexBrighton and HoveRedbridgeBarking and Dagenham It comes as a doctors union said it no longer opposes the reopening of schools on June .The British Medical Association said evidence shows the risk to kids is extremely small, but schools should only reopenit is “safe to do so.Last week, doctors said it was too risky for kids toto schools, despite the countrys biggest primary school chains backing the Governments plans.In an apparent softening of its stance, the British Medical Associationhas admitted there was “growing evidence that the risk to inidual children from Covid- is extremely small.However, it warned there was still no consensus around how easily kids could spread the disease to vulnerable adults.Writing for The , Dr Peter English, the chairman of the BMA’s Public Health Medicine Committee, said: “The BMA wants schools to reopen as soon as it is safe to do so and the evidence allows – this could be before June  or after.A zero-risk approach is not possible. This is about ‘safe’ being an acceptable level of risk.”Dame Angela McLean, the deputy chief scientic adviser, said an effective track and trace system was needed to isolate those infected by the coronavirus before changes were made to lockdown rules.She told The Times that this should be based on observed levels of infection . . . and not on a fixed date.And scientist John Edmunds, another member of SAGE, told Sky News that a track and trace system must be embedded and working well before schools re-opened.Teaching unions are opposed to the Governments plan to re-open schools on June , claiming teachers, pupils and their families will be at risk of catching the deadly virus.They were backed last week by the British Medical Association, who said unions were absolutely right to urge caution and prioritise testing before reopening schools on June .BMA councils chair, Chaand Nagpaul, the BMA councils chair, said at the time: We cannot risk a second spike or take actions which would increase the spread of this virus, particularly as we see sustained rates of infection across the UK.Kevin Courtney, the joint general secretary of the National Education Union , refused to back down ahead with reopening schools.”According to the Daily Mail, its leaders were caught making a series of slurs in a Zoom meeting last night.The video footage exposed the joint general secretary Mary Bousted accusing children of being mucky by spreading germs and wiping their snot on peoples clothes.The hard-line leaders also discussed how to threaten head teachers should they try to get their or teachers who refuse to reopen schools on June  wont be fined, Priti Patel has declared.The Home Secretary today insisted it was not the right approach to slap those against the Governments plan with fines.She said: “First of all, we are not at the st of June yet, we have time to work together.Its wrong to sort of say well X needs a sanction or Y needs a sanction.But Ms Patel insisted there title: kfc customer horrified after finding feathers poking out
story: The shocked customer slammed the fast food chain as she shared pictures of the fried chicken online, saying she “won’t ever eat KFC again”.The Blackpool woman ordered a KFC from their Cornelian Way branch using Uber Eats, and was left horried after she spotted three feathers poking out from one of the hot wings.The appalled customer posted pictures of food on a community food page yesterday, and said her young son thought the feathers looked like small legs.The woman, who did not want to be named, said: “I have received an apology, refund and also been told that in no circumstances should I have been sent that food.“KFC should not [be] giving this to a customer, surely it’s not good food hygiene to leave feathers attachedthat’s what they are.”The woman later got half her money back from Uber Eats – an £. refund.She told LancashireLive: “I won’t ever eat KFC again.“Because I ordered from Uber Eats I only got a partial refund just for the meal even though the lot was wasted.“When I went to KFC the manager just came over to my car in the car park and he couldn’t give me a refund as I had ordered from Uber.”A KFC spokesman said the feathers were harmless, but said the incident doesnt meet the Colonels usual high standards.He said: Not ideal. Feathers can happen when dealing with fresh chicken - they’re harmless, but it goes without saying they shouldn’t be there.It doesn’t meet the Colonel’s usual high standards, and it’s certainly not the reunion we want people to have with their favourite fried chicken after some time apart! We’re sorry we missed them, so we’d like to invite the customer to get in touch with us and we will make things right.”It comes after a diner in Scotland found a feather in his KFC burger last month.The customer had picked up four mini fillet burgers and two drinks at the firm’s branch in Kilmarnock, Ayrshire and said the experience “put him off KFC for le.”“I took the burger straight back when I saw this.”The woman ordered her meal through Uber Eats from the Cornelian Way branchOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: newly discovered footage tasmanian tiger
story: Shot in , the amazing clip emerged after it was digitally restored by experts from the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.The -second segment comes from a travelogue called Tasmania the Wonderland believed to have been shot by filmmaker and exhibitor Sidney Cook.It captures Benjamin - the last-known surviving thylacine  - at Beaumaris Zoo in Hobart, Tasmania.The fact the video was shot in  makes it the most recent moving images of the now extinct animal.Benjamin died just  months after this startling footage was captured.His death marked the extinction of the species after another specimen died at London Zoo in .Thylacines were large carnivorous marsupials which looked like a cross between a wolf and a big cat.The slow-moving predators hunted kangaroos as well as other marsupials, rodents and small birds.They once lived throughout Australia but became extinct on the mainland around , years ago.It was then confined to the island of Tasmania until they were eventually killed off by dogs and hunters.On the clip Benjamin can be seen pacing around while two men rattle his cage.The narrator says the beast is now very rare, being forced out of its natural habitat by the march of civilization.The scarcity of thylacine footage makes every second of moving image really precious, said NFSA Curator Simon Smith.Were very excited to make this newly-digitised footage available to everyone online.Despite its extinction, Tasmanias Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and Environment released a document in October detailing eight reported sightings in recent years.However, there has been no hard evidence to support the claims .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teachers schools ready work children back
story: WE cannot wait to see the children back in our schools — teaching them is what we do.While you may hear that teachers’ representatives are not keen for theto the classroom, the reality is completely dferent on the ground.Teachers, generally, really want to help get schools going again.We have just heard from  across our Trust’s schools and over  per cent of them have said they are ready to get back to work.This idea that they are standing in the way of a national effort couldn’t be further from the truth.Our teachers have gone above and beyond the call of duty during this crisis.We have kept the schools open, bank holidays and weekends, for those vulnerable children and those children of key workers.No teacher has ever complained, they have all served their time on a rota.They have been doing amazing work online, marking and preparing for that work, giving feedback.There are bound to be factions and nervousness within the profession, because the health of pupils and staff is a high stakes issue.I am the immediate past president of the Association of School and College Leaders.Our union thinks the right thing to do is to plan, in a considered way, for afrom June .Dferent trade unions have dferent tactics and are using dferent language.We have had hard questions to ask, in regard to safety and how to make it effective.I am not a medic or scientist, so I cannot judge whether we need personal protective equipment.But I can understand the rationale of the Government’s chief medical officer Chris Whitty, when he warns that children fiddling with masks, taking them off and on, is likely to be a greater risk than not having them.Plus, it distracts from the most important measures — which are regular hand washing, good nasal hygiene and making sure we keep things clean in school.The scientic advice is that transmission of Covid- within the school environment is very, very low because of the way in which the virus works in younger people.Based on what we have heard so far from Chris Whitty and the guidance we have seen we think it is safe to put government plans into action.We think we can put the measures in place to reassure parents and staff that it’s the right thing to do.Head teachers are planning for that in detail right now, which is very complex.For example, we have been told we need lidded bins, so everyone is rushing out to buy them.We need to make sure the signage is right, the air conditioning is working, the school is clean.Then you have to deal with the logistics of a maximum of  pupils per class, with a two-metre distance between each pupil.We are working out how many pupils are going to come back, how many staff are available and how much building space have I got There are very good reasons for all these endeavours.It is important for a child’s social and emotional well-being to be able to meet friends at school.We know that children’s access to learning at home will be very iable, because of dferent home broadband speeds and availability of computers.Not everyone has parents who are able to teach them at home.The learning they are missing will be hard to catch up and we don’t want the “coronials”, as they are being referred to, to miss out.They have endured this crisis and now need to be pushed forward to fill the gap in their learning.In our Trust one school in Leeds has  per cent of its pupils on free school meals, while in another the percentage is four or five per cent.We know that those children who don’t have access to great home learning are at a disadvantage.All children need our care and attention, but we worry most about the children whose homes are not a happy or safe place to be.Our message to the Government and everyone  is to work together on the best way to get back into the classroom.We need to work constructively, to chart a way through what is a very complex problem.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on title: aunt woman chopped in half forest of dean
story: Phoenix Netts, , is thought to have been living at a womens refuge in Birmingham when she was killed.Her body was later dumped in the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire. Police fear she had been sawn in half and burned.Her devastated aunt, Ana-Liliana Netts, , opened up about the horror of hearing about her nieces tragic death.She told the Mail Online: Im shocked that she has died in such a horric way.I hadnt seen her since she was little, but she was a lovely, sweet-natured girl. Her father used to tell me proudly how clever she was.She used to live in Croydon, she was from a very nice family. They must be heartbroken.I always remember her as a nice little girl. Im so sorry she died like this.Phoenixs family issued an emotional statement in response to her tragic death on May .It read: “As a family we are devastated with what has happened to Phoenix.“We have family and good friends supporting us and our thanks go out to all of them.“We would also like to thank all the police officers involved in the investigation for their hard work and sensitivity.Meanwhile friends of Miss Netts have paid tribute, with one saying: I can’t believe it is her. She was a lovely girl. I thought she had got away from all this.Neighbour Wahidur Rahman, , said: Phoenix was a really nice young girl. She was lovely.I thought something might have happened to her because I hadn’t seen her in a while.It comes after two people appeared in court on Tuesday charged over Phoenixs killing.Gareeca Conita Gordon, , who also lived at the seven-bed refuge in Birmingham, has been charged with murder after the grim discovery was made last week.Married dad-of-two Mahesh Sorathiya, , from Wolverhampton, was charged with assisting an offender after the body parts were discovered.A provisional trial date was set for November  this year.Neighbours reported Phoenix lived at the same womens refuge in Birmingham as Gordon.It is understood the woman was last seen in April with her phone disconnected on Tuesday.Forensic officers were seen at the council-licensed refuge at the weekend combing for clues.Neighbour Wahidur Rahman, , said: Phoenix was a really nice young girl. She was lovely.We didnt know her well - all the women in the refuge kept themselves to themselves. They were all vulnerable in a way.Its so shocking that shes been killed and then cut up.I thought something might have happened to her because I hadnt seen her in a while.The forensics have been in her bedroom for a few days now and today they blacked out the windows.Theyve been taking away bags of belongings.Im just in shock, really. She was a pretty young girl.Tradesman Sorathiya moved to Wolverhampton three years ago from Slough, Berkshire, with his we. The Indian couple are said to have two teenage children.Cops swooped on a man and woman who were said to be driving suspiciously near Coleford, Gloucestershire.They discovered the body parts stuffed in two suitcases. It is understood there had been attempts to burn the remains.Officers later raided a property in Birmingham and discovered the grisly murder scene which is said to have resembled an abattoir, The Sun understands.The judge granted conditional bail to Sorathiya, but no application for bail was made on behalf of Gordon today.Gordon is accused of murder between April  and May , while Sorathiya is accused of assisting her between April  and May .Detective Chief Inspector Scott Grfiths from our homicide team said: “Firstly, I’d like to offer my sincere condolences to Phoenix’s family.“We’ve worked closely with colleagues at Gloucestershire over the past week and our investigation continues at pace.“We’d urge anyone with any information about the tragic loss of Phoenix’s le to get in touch with us.

title: michael gove brussels brexit ideological world economy coronavirus
story: No  has challenged Brussels to ditch its ideological Brexit stance for the good of the coronavirus battered world economy.Michael Gove said there was a powerful incentive for the bloc to compromise and get a deal - warning failure to do so will hit its global reputation.In a move that will heap further pressure on embattled Michel Barnier he even accused eurocrats of putting bureaucracy before people.He said: There is a very powerful incentive for the EU to put the interests of its members and its citizens ahead of ideology.The Cabinet Office minister said the success of the negotiations depends on the EU recognising the UK is a sovereign equal.He told MPs: The EU essentially wants us to obey the rules of their club even though were no longer members.And they want the same access to our fishing grounds as they currently enjoy while restricting our access to their markets.It remains dficult to reach a mutually beneficial agreement while the EU maintains such an ideological approach.But we believe agreement is possibleflexibility is shown.Downing St has published a complete set of legal texts outlining the deal it wants - meaning they can be examined by Member States for the first time.The move comes after UK officials expressed concerns Mr Barnier is struggling to get the attention of EU capitals busy fighting coronavirus.British negotiators hope it will persuade European leaders to get more involved and move on from the blocs hardline stance.They say talks with the Frenchman have hit an impasse as his hands are tied by an un-negotiable mandate.The texts call for a simple Canada-style free trade agreement under which the UK would break free from Brussels red tape.They also outline a separate Norway-style fishing pact, with annual negotiations over access for EU vessels to British waters.Mr Barnier had a dig at how long the UK had kept the texts secret - pointing out Brussels published its plan for a deal two months ago.The PMs chief negotiator David Frost last night accused Mr Barnier of singling out the UK for unfair treatment.In a fiery letter he demanded to know why the bloc wont offer Britain the same access for goods and services it gives many other countries.And he slammed the EU chiefs argument the UK must pay a higher price for a trade deal because of how close it is as hard to justy.He wrote: We find it hard to see what makes the UK, uniquely among your trading partners, so unworthy of being offered the kind of well-precedented arrangements commonplace in modern FTAs.What is on offer is not a fair free trade relationship between close economic partners, but a relatively low-quality trade agreement coming with unprecedented EU oversight of our laws and institutions.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - title: every adult now organ donor unless opt out
story: Most adults in England are now organ donors unless they opt out thanks to two inspiring children.Max and Keira’s law takes effect today and will lead to  additional transplants each year by .Keira Ball was nine when she passed away three days after she was in a horric car crash near her home in Devon in July  which left her with serious head injuries.Her family took the heartbreaking decision to allow her to become an organ donor, motivated by her desire to help others.At the same time Max Johnson, , was fighting for his le at the Freeman Hospital in Newcastle and needed a heart transplant to save him.Maxs family later received a phone call saying an organ had been found and was a match.The primary school pupil then received her heart in a le-saving operation.Little Max campaigned to bring about the new law after Keira’s organs saved four lives in total, including another young boy who received her pancreas and liver.Max and Keiras law sees a sht to an opt-out system, whereby those aged  and over are deemed to have given consent to donate their own organs when they die, unless they explicitly state otherwise or are in an excluded group.Faizan Awan, one of thousands of people across the UK awaiting a transplant, said: For many people like me, who are waiting for an organ, the law change is a sign of hope and a transplant would dramatically change my le in a number of ways.With the new law coming into effect, it is now more important than ever to talk about organ donation and get the conversation going amongst our family and friends.Anthony Clarkson, director of organ and tissue donation and transplantation at NHS Blood and Transplant , said: We hope this law change will prompt all of us to consider whether or not we would want to donate our organs and encourage us all to register and share our decision with our family and friends.He added that people should be aware they will still have a choice on whether or not to donate, and reassured the public that families will still be consulted, and faith, beliefs and culture will continue to be respected.The change in law has been widely welcomed by charities including the British Heart Foundation and Kidney Care UK.In  a similar law was introduced in Wales.Scotland is due to have similar legislation in place by Autumn , whereas Ireland continues to have an opt in system.Our title: girls foot chopped off lawnmower
story: Little Maisie Baker tripped over while her grandfather was mowing the lawn and the blades severed off her right big toe and her entire left foot.Her horried mum felt something hit her leg and thought it was a rock - until she realised that it was her daughters foot.Emma feared that Maisie would bleed to death as she desperately stemmed the blood flow until paramedics rushed the little girl to hospital.Surgeons at Addenbrookes Hospital, Cambridge, spent  hours cleaning the wound and reattaching the flesh - and even after two more operations Maisie may still face her foot having to be amputated.Devastated mum Emma, , is now speaking out about the accident to warn others to keep their children inside when mowing the lawn and is crowdfunding to provide for Maisies recovery.Emma, from Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, said: Its heartbreaking. Its the worst thing that anyone could even dream about. It doesnt seem real.Her grandfather feels distraught. He is constantly crying. He feels guilty. He doesnt know how to react or what to do to make it better.Its very frustrating because of the coronavirus, he is unable to visit to try and console her and speak to her about it. Obviously there have been options of FaceTiming but its not enough.Stay inside when mowing and do not go out at all when there is a lawnmower in the garden. It takes a second.With just one parent allowed to visit Maisie at a time due to coronavirus restrictions, Emma and dad Chris, , are taking it in turns to be by her bedside.The couple anticipates that their daughter will need to leave hospital in a wheelchair and will need physiotherapy and counselling to recover - with the possibility of prosthetics not ruled out.The couple are fundraising to pay for Maisies future treatment and have raised more than £, so far.You can donate to Maisies cause here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sir captain tom moore knighthood queen
story: CAPTAIN Tom Moore is thrilled to be honoured with a knighthood - but has today vowed to keep his conversation with the gracious Queen secret.The  year-old World War Two veterans knighthood was announced by Downing Street on Monday night.It was approved by the Queen, having been personally recommended and fast-tracked by the Prime Minister.And the inspirational vet today told Good Morning Britain said he had been floored by the honour.He said: Im absolutely thrilled that Her Majesty has decided that poor little me will be knighted.It really is a great honour and I never believed this would happen to me but the Queen is so gracious that she has bestowed this honour on me and I really am totally thrilled by it.I really am thrilled and I do appreciate all the kind words people have offered about me being knighted.But when host Piers Morgan asked what Captain Moore would say to the Queenhe got to meet her, the polite vet declined to answer.He said: The discussion between me and the Queen will have to be kept secret.I dont believe youre meant to say what the Queen says, so as I shall say, as to all you people, Ill say thank you very much Queen.His daughter Hannah Hannah Ingram-Moore joked the family had even been practising their curtseying for any future possible royal meeting.The gong is the first of dozens for the heroes of the debilitating crisis, The Sun can also reveal.The Government is to issue a special honours list in the Autumn to recognise everyone who has performed with distinction through out it.It is expected to be dominated by NHS staff, and the public will be able to nominate specic iniduals who cared for them.The news was broken to Tom by his daughter Hannah, who he is isolating with at his home in Marston Moretaine, Bedfordshire.Hannah was told in a phone call from the PM’s most senior official, his Principal Private Secretary Martin Reynolds.The centurion won the hearts of a nation after vowing to walk  laps of his Bedfordshire garden to raise money for the NHS.His initial fundraising target was £,.After his plea for sponsorship went viral, the former infantry officer ended up reaping an extraordinary £m in donations - a Guinness title: pubs could open from july with social distancing minister says
story: Environment Secretary George Eustice stressed again that the nations boozers were still on track to open in weeks, as long as they could space out customers.Mr Eustice told the Commons: Of course we also recognise that until thingsto something closer to normal and they can open normally, hopefully later this summer, then it will not give them all of the trade they previously had.And he added: As the Prime Minister has outlined, we intend that the hospitality sector including pubs would be able to tentatively start gradually opening hopefully during the month of July – subject to the epidemiology supporting such a move.And of course we are already working with the hospitality and pub sector to identy what social distancing measures they might be able to put in place to make that work properly.Mr Eustices comments echoed Dominic Raabs remarks earlier this month, who said pubs and restaurants would be not open until July  at the earliest.He had said: From th July, at the earliest, well look at other sectors and that will include hospitality, but it will also include personal care and people like hairdressers.Obviously the proximity in those two sectors is something where we dont think were ready yet, given where we are with the virus.However, it will likely only include pubs with outdoor spaces or enough room to make sure that groups can keep apart.Scientists say that the virus spreads more in enclosed spaces, and the risk is less outside.Brewers and pubs have suggested that the two metre rule could be reduced to one to open up pubs once again.And the British Beer and Pub Association last week warned that Britain’s , pubs faced pouring as many as  million untouched pints away.BBPA chief executive Emma McClarkin said: “Re-opening in July will be great for those pubs who can meet the social-distancing measures required by then.We stand ready to work with the Government to help pubs re-open in a safe and financially viable way as soon as possible.“Actioning advice from the WHO for example to use one metre for social distancing from July would enable many more pubs to viably re-open and serve their communities again.In mid-May Boris Johnson laid out the first careful steps of easing the coronavirus lockdown as part of a three-phase plan to get back to normal le.In an address to the nation he revealed a detailed roadmap of how to get Britain back on its feet, but still keep the deadly virus under control.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: weather brits 28c sunshine
story: Sunbathers made the most of their new-found freedom following the easing of lockdown restrictions as Londons St Jamess Park saw a high of .C on Tuesday - the highest recorded this year.And the sunshine is set to continue for most of the UK on Wednesday, with temperatures expected to hit C.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said: “A warm start to the day on Wednesday.“For most it’s dry and it’s increasingly sunny during Wednesday afternoon, with temperatures reaching mid-s widely, and up to C in the South East.“It stays warm and bright into the evening, but you can see some thicker cloud approaching Northern Ireland, and outbreaks of rain.”He predicted the hottest day of the year so far, with temperatures in the s and highs of C in the London area.The hot weather is likely to be a test of the new lockdown measures after Boris Johnson announced that Brits can now spend as much time as they like outside – as long as social distancing is observed.Local councils have urged Brits to stick to social distancing and reminded the public that facilities such as outdoor pools and public toilets remained closes.Officers will also be patrolling popular beauty spots and parks to ensure people are abiding by the government’s guidance.Tourist spots have also asked people to stay away with many attractions remaining closed – with the majority beaches not being leguarded.After today’s heatwave, there is a risk of thunderstorms on Thursday in East and South East England as a band of rain pushes eastwards.Temperatures are predicted to cool from C or C before the rain to a fresher C to C on Friday.Met Office meteorologist Greg Dewhurst said: There will be a bit of a grey, misty start for some first thing but that will quickly burn away.The vast majority of the UK will have a dry day with sunny spells,not blue skies all day for some.Mr Dewhurst predicted a windy start to the weekend with sunshine and showers for many with the weather gradually turning drier from the south on Sunday and into bank holiday Monday.While there has been no immediate end to the lockdown, the easing of restrictions meant plenty made the most of the sun – sunbathing and enjoying picnics.The PM
