title: organ donation max keira law opt out
story: With Max and Keiras Law coming into effect today, heres everything you need to know.Organ donation is when someone gives an organ to help someone who needs a transplant.There is no age limit on being a donor, but a few medical conditions can prevent you from donating.You can donate after death or as a living donation.The latter only applies to donating a kidney, a small part of your liver, bone from a hip or knee replacement or your placenta.Max and Keiras Law is the new organ donor system which comes into effect on May , .The new rules mean that everyone over  will donate their organs for transplant when they die, unless they actively register their wish not to.But families will still be involved before organ donation goes ahead.Under-s, people with limited mental capacity and others who have not lived in England for at least a year prior to their death will be exempt from the scheme.Parents will still be able to give consent for those under  years old to donate their organs upon death.Those who do not wish to donate can record this on the NHS register either online or by phone.The legislation is named after Max Johnson and Keira Ball.When Keira, nine, was killed in a car crash, her heart was donated to save the le of Max, also nine, who would have otherwise died from heart failure.Wales switched to a presumed consent system in December  where deceased adults are considered agreeing to donate unless they opt out.Organ donation and transplants have since risen sharply, with just six per cent of the adult population opting out.Theresa May proposed a wider move to this systemduring a speech at the Tory party conference in Manchester in .She said: Our ability to help people who need transplants is limited by the number of organ donors that come forward.That is why [in ]  people died because a suitable organ was not available. The animal was pursued across a field by a pack of dogs as mounted riders were nearby. Campaigners released the video, which was filmed in November, after police and prosecutors decided against taking action against the hunt involved. The shocking film, which lasts one minute,  seconds, shows two riders and about a dozen dogs near a hedge on the edge of a field.  After about a minute, the hounds break off and begin barking as they run down the field. Eventually a fox can be seen running away towards a tree, while a horn can be heard in the background. Sheep in a neighbouring field can be seen running away, and the dogs skirt the edge of the first field along the hedgerow before the footage breaks off. The incident, which unfolded near Okeford Fitzpaine, Dorset and appeared to involve the Portman Hunt, was filmed by Wildle Witness and reported to police. A Wildle Witness spokesman said: “It is sickening to watch this happening  years after hunting was banned. “The legislation needs tightening to prevent foxes being subjected to such terror.  “We will continue to monitor the activities of hunts and bring in to the public domain the reality of what is happening in our countryside.” Hunting with hounds was banned on February ,  following the  Hunting Act’s approval by Parliament. But trail hunting, where where riders accompanied by hounds follow a scent along a pre-determined route, is allowed. It is meant to replicate a traditional hunt but without a fox being chased, maimed or killed. Dorset Police confirmed it received a report “in relation to an alleged illegal fox hunt that had been witnessed in the area of Okeford Fitzpaine near Blandford”.  A force spokesman said a “local officer carried out an investigation into the incident and two men attended for voluntary interviews with officers”. The spokesman added: “Evidence was compiled and following consultation with the Crown Prosecution Service, a decision was made not to bring any charges in relation to the case. “Dorset Police will investigate any alleged breached of the Hunting Act  and other legislation and will work closely with the Crown Prosecution Service to determinea case could be taken to court. “Hunting mammals with dogs has been illegal since .  “A few, very specic, exemptions apply. “We would urge anyone with clear evidence of such offending to please report it to us.” A spokesman for the Portman Hunt said: “The Portman Hunt operates within the law by carrying out lawful trail hunting activities. “As has been proven on numerous occasions in court, the evidence provided by anti-hunting activists almost always fails to support their claims of illegal hunting activity. “This has been proven yet again by the authorities investigating this case who have said there will be no further action. “Anti-hunting activists are aware that the circulation of their edited footage online using social media s can amply their highly emotive messages, regardless of the facts, but this often results in hundreds of hours of wasted police time, which is totally unacceptable.” League Against Cruel Sports campaigns director Chris Luffingham said: “If ‘trail’ hunting is real then in no circumstances should animals be chased by hounds, it simply wouldn’t happen.

story: NewsLib Dem leadership election to start on June  after coronavirus delayLayla Moran and Wera Hobhouse have already thrown their hats into the ring in the race, whose winner will be announced after August ShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPrevious leader Jo Swinson lost her seat in the  election " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe on-off Lib Dem leadership race is back on again, with the party hunting for its third boss in less than a year. MP Jo Swinson won a contest last summer before losing her Scottish seat at last Decemberaposs general election. Her deputy Sir Ed Davey has been holding the reins ever since – and a battle for the crown was due to kick off this month. Education spokeswoman Layla Moran and environment spokesman Wera Hobhouse had already thrown their hats into the ring. But the race was shelved for a year amid the coronavirus crisis – before today being rescheduled yet again. The contest will now begin on June  with nominations closing on July . The winner will be announced after August . Ms Moran, , said: “I welcome the decision to bring the contest forward. After the last ten years, the Liberal Democrats are at a crossroads. I look forward to setting out a revived and compassionate liberal vision at this pivotal moment in our countryaposs history.  “From my listening sessions, I know that many people share my aspirations for an economy which respects key-workers and leaves no-one behind, a world-leading education system that puts trust in teachers, and a renewed fight against bioersity loss and the climate emergency. “I will continue listening as leader, to make our party stronger and more inclusive.  “I want to rebuild the Lib Dems’ campaigning strength so that we can start delivering on this vision, and start winning again for communities across the UK.  “Thataposs why I’m standing to be the next Leader of the Liberal Democrats, to rebuild the Party at this crucial time.” The party, which has just  MPs and last week published a damning verdict on its disastrous election campaign, hopes to attract some attention during the two-month battle. Ms Hobhouse, , said: This is a good decision for the Liberal Democrat Party. “The election review that came out over the weekend was tough reading, but it was honest, and shows that we need to make some big changes. We need a new leader to do that. “As the review stated, we had two choices at the last election, but we sat on the fence. “We need a new direction. “My leadership pitch is clear we need to fight from the centre left, and build a winning, progressive alliance. “This is how we beat the Tories at the next election.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Outsourcing giant Serco has apologised after it accidentally shared almost  email addresses of new recruits to the Governmentaposs coronavirus contact-tracing programme.The company is helping to sign up people to support efforts to track and trace cases of Covid- to help reduce the spread of the disease in the UK. The Government has promised to recruit , contact tracers to manually gather information about the places infected people have visited and other iniduals they have been in contact with to get a detailed picture of who might be at risk of infection. The error at Serco saw  addresses being included in a CCsection of an email rather than BCC , meaning they were visible to recipients. It is understood that all the affected recruits had given the company permission to use their personal email addresses. No information other than the email addresses was shared. Serco is not intending to noty the Information Commissioneraposs Officefollowing the error and is not aware of a complaint being made. A spokesman for the company said: An email was sent to new recruits who had given us their permission to use their personal email addresses.  In error, email addresses were visible to other recipients. We have apologised and reviewed our processes to make sure that this does not happen again. Justice Secretary Robert Buckland said: Serco has apologised, rightly, for that mistake. It brings into stark relief the importance about privacy, about confidentiality, which underpins all of this. With theapp being developed, the Government has got that issue of privacy very much in mind in making sure we can have maximum confidence because these systems will only workwe get a signicant part of the population taking part. That is why I think Serco was right to apologise quickly.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA top Tory has admitted the government chose not to test people for coronavirus in care homes for more than a month while the pandemic spread. Robert Buckland accepted we needed to make a choice about what to do with the capacity the government had back in March. The Justice Secretary added there are now huge issues in care homes - at least % of which have a Covid- outbreak with more than , deaths. He told Sky News: We’ve seen a great tragedy in our care homes which is a matter of huge regret. It is a rare admission from the government that it was a choice to stop widespread testing in care homes.  Shadow Care Minister Liz Kendall said: This is the clearest admission yet that ministers did not give care homes the protection they needed at the start of this pandemic.“Social care and the NHS are both equally important in the fight against this virus and are inextricably linked. One cannot be prioritised above the other. “Ministers must give social care the resources, support and attention it needs to stop the spread of this awful virus.”Care home residents, new arrivals and staff with symptoms were not routinely tested from mid-March, when community testing ended due to lack of capacity, to April . Testing has since ramped up to around , a day and there has been a pledge to test all staff and residents, even without symptoms - but that will only be fully rolled out by June . Until April , not even new arrivals into care homes from hospitals were routinely tested. Only last night one Cabinet minister, George Eustice, insisted: We don’t accept the caricature that we took an approach that was wrong. But Dame Angela McLean, Chief Scientic Advisor to the Ministry of Defence, said bluntly: With the testing we had, the right thing to do was to focus it on people who were really sick in hospital. It was the right thing to do at the time.  And today Mr Buckland accepted it was a choice to test in the NHS over care homes. Asked what mistakes the government made, he told Sky News: Well I think we widely emphasised the importance of making sure our NHS services and our hospitals were places that could continue to admit patients and wouldnapost be incubators of the disease. We achieved that, we protected our NHS, we ramped up our capability, which meant it didnapost thankfully fall over at a time of huge pressure. Askedhe was saying the government focused on the NHS to the detriment of care homes, he replied: Well look, I think we needed to make a choice about testing, and we did decide to focus upon the NHS.  I think the issue with care homes is that we’ve got many thousands of dferent providers, dferent settings. There have been lots of examples of care homes that have mercully stayed infection free, but sadly far too many cases of infection and death. I think every country in the world will look back and say there were things we could have done dferently, but I think now weaposve got to focus on the here and now.  Asked againthe NHS had been focused on first and foremost at the start of the outbreak, he said: Thataposs right, and I think that was absolutely essential. Now is not time to blame people. I think that would be wholly counterproductive.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThree generations of one family who all caught and beat coronavirus have spoken out about their extraordinary battle with the disease. Keri Rennison, , a mental health nurse, lives with fiancé Chris Westoby, , as well as her daughter Rosie, , and her parents Paul, , and Jackie, . But their family le changed drastically when every family member contracted covid-, forcing each of them to self-isolate in their own rooms. Keri says because she and Chris are keyworkers, they must have brought it into the house, highlighting that living in a multi-generational home during lockdown has its downside as well as the obvious advantages. Chris, who works in food processing, had developed a cough over a couple of days, and shortly after father-in-law Paul started feeling unwell.Speaking to HullLive, Paul said: Me and Jackie had come home from the allotment and I didnapost feel very well.I cooked Sunday lunch, it was roast beef but my heart just wasnapost in it. I sat down to eat and said I don’t want this - which just isnapost me. I took myself to bed and then didnapost get out for nearly two weeks. While Paul struggled with the early stages of the virus, Keri and Chris continued working, as they were both key workers. Speaking about the living situation, with her parents moving into their home in Hull back in , Keri couldnapost help but worry about the impact of their work on the household. She said: It’s a positive weaposve been able to lockdown together but the negative is, itaposs either myself or Chris whoaposve brought the virus in as key workers - thereaposs that realisation thatwe didnapost live in this way my dad might not have got it. Chris added: The positive side is that we were there to care for him. If he was ill somewhere  and we couldnapost see him that would have been terrible. But as Paulaposs symptoms persisted, the family decided to completely isolate, with Keri and Jackie taking it in turns to test his temperature. On Thursday, April , however, he took a turn for the worse. Jackie said: We were doing these tests and thinking please don’t let it reach this and please don’t let it reach that. It was so scary. If I’d had been on my own I would have gone to pieces completely because I didnapost know what to do, Keri took charge and she saw to it all. When paramedics arrived, they decided Paul needed to go to the hospital. Rosie said: It was really scary. He didnapost say much, just ‘I’ll see you soon’. But at that point how do you know you’re going to see someone again because you hear of people going in and never coming out again. He was a shell of the man he is - it really broke my heart.  Jackie said: It was awful. I turned to Rosie and I said aposIaposm never going to see him againapos. It still upsets me.Paul was given a coronavirus test, which came back positive, but thankfully, his condition was not bad enough to warrant a stay overnight on the Covid ward.He was sent home, but the rest of the family quickly came down with coronavirus symptoms. As a key worker, Keri was able to get tested and the result came back positive, confirming that it had spread through the house. Chris said: It was terrible. I was better by then and I was asking peopleI could do anything or make them things to eat but nobody wanted anything. It was so strange, like nothing Iaposve ever experienced before. Keri said that none of her family had either of the major symptoms of a persistent cough and a high fever. She said: It started with a loss of taste and sense of smell that has only just come back but itaposs still very, very weak. And then I had fatigue and a headache for seven days after. My father was really the only one who had any sort of respiratory dficulties, which was just shortness of breath when he spoke. But as a family we realised that weaposre very, very lucky to have only got the symptoms mild and survived it. Most of all weaposre really thankful.

Haven, Center Parcs and Butlin’s are drawing up plans to adapt their sites to cater for families’ “pent-up demand to get away” while sticking to vital social distancing rules.They are hoping the Government clears holiday parks and resorts to reopen in July – under what would be Phase Three of Boris Johnson ’s plan to ease us out of lockdown and reboot the hospitality sector.It comes after Visit Britain said the domestic market, worth £billion, has already lost £billion as a result of Covid- measures. The group wants families to make  the “year of domestic tourism”. Acting chief executive Patricia Yates told the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee: “To get British tourism up and running this summer – and the summer is hugely important – you’re going to need that domestic audience.” She added there was “a real job to be done” to convince people it is acceptable to “enjoy a holiday and that it’s safe to do so”. But figures from coolcamping. com, covering  locations, show summer bookings for campsites have soared % in the past week. The website said: “There’s clearly a pent-up demand to get away. The mooted date of July  is ideal timing for summer and could save many businesses who have had no income.” Rethinks on how resorts and parks operate will help reassure people mulling a staycation. Haven says planned measures range from Perspex screens at reception and info desks to check-ins from home. On-site grocery stores will have the same social distancing rules as supermarkets, while restaurants will just do takeaways and deliveries. Hand- washing stations will be dotted around all  parks and there will be reduced numbers on sites – with communal areas like swimming pools will staying closed.Haven said: “Our prices have been adjusted to recognise the revised experience. We’ve made signicant changes, which we anticipate will allow us to open as soon as Government deems it safe. We’ll comply with coronavirus restrictions.”Center Parcs, which has six UK sites, is also hoping to reopen in July and said holidaymakers could expect to see “some changes”. A spokesman said: “We are reviewing the whole experience to ensure we can open with appropriate social distancing as well as any other measures required to keep our staff and guests safe. “We know we can adapt and provide reassurance to guests and staff, and will only reopen when the time is right. When we do, we are confident we will provide a great guest experience for families.” Butlin’s said fewer people would be allowed in entertainment venues and it would increase the number of shows. There will be more sittings for meals as well as extra events so that kids do not miss out on activities. The firm said: “We are awaiting guidance as to when we can reopen. “In the meantime, we’re using all of the skills and creativity of our team to plan a break that keeps everyone safe.” The Camping and Caravanning Club, which represents , sites, said caravanners will park six metres apart and tents will also be pitched with large gaps between them. Its plans include asking campers and caravan owners to bring their own portable loos so toilets can stay closed. Bosses offered to do a trial reopening after losing £million of bookings due to Covid-. Camping and Caravanning Club director general Sabina Voysey said: “We’re well-placed to offer socially-distanced holidays and eager to work on trial schemes for how campsites may reopen with all necessary measures. “We urge the Government to provide greater clarity on how the sector can safely open and operate.” The plans to get staycations firmly on the radar emerged as airlines slammed a bid by Transport Secretary Grant Shapps to boost uptake of foreign holidays as unworkable. Mr Shapps raised hopes of travel to top hotspots by striking up no-quarantine deals, or “air bridges”, with countries where infection rates are low. Britain’s biggest tour operator, Tui, said it hopes to kick-start the season from June . The firm got a boost after Portugal and Greece revealed they were willing to relax quarantine restrictions for Britsit was a two-way system. Algarve Tourism Board head Joao Fernandes said: “If British holidaymakers are allowed to fly to countries with low infection rates via ‘air bridges’, without having the need for quarantine, the Algarve will be the place to be.” But airlines said the scheme was at odds with the Government’s two- week quarantine rules for anyone coming into the UK, effective from next month, and a Foreign Office ban on non-essential travel abroad. The PM’s official spokesman said air bridges were “an option under consideration but not agreed policy”.

Max and Keira’s Law, which came after a four-year campaign by the Mirror for an opt-out rule, does not apply to under s and parents still have to give permission for doctors to use their children’s organs. But Roseleila and Richard could face an even longer wait due to the ­coronavirus pandemic.  Some patients have had to be taken off the transplant list because the risk to them of receiving an organ is too high. No one who dies showing Covid- symptoms can donate. Those who are able to be treated, such as kidney patients on dialysis, may be expected to wait longer for operations. But those in dire need of transplants, who would die without an organ, will still have surgery. Max was given his heart by the family of nine-year-old Keira Ball, who died in a car accident near her home at ­Barnstaple, Devon, in . She also saved three others. His parents Paul, , and Emma, , and Keira’s mum Loanna and dad Joe are working hard to raise awareness of the new law – which was inspired by their children. Loanna, , who was seriously injured in the crash that killed her daughter, said: “Max and Keira will be remembered long after we are gone. “This law is so important. They really will go down in history, they will never be forgotten. That means so much.” The couple’s charity, Inspired by Keira, is helping bereaved parents cope with the loss of a child. And they worked tirelessly to help the , currently on the organ donor list. Loanna and Joe also work hard to reassure parents who might consider organ donationthe ­unthinkable were to happen, and they were to lose a child. Paul and Emma, of Winsford, Cheshire, wrote a book called Golden Heart, in which they vividly describe the ordeal of parents whose children are on the transplant list. For Max, it was nine months on a ward at Newcastle’s Freeman Hospital looking out of the window, wonderingand when he might be saved.  Even at , he was thinking of others, admitting he might not make it. But he still believed the new law was right. For five-year-old Frankie Lord, who was in the Freeman at the same time as Max and featured in the Mirror on Tuesday, it was a -month wait for his parents Sophie and Chris as they watched the agony of their little boy clinging to le. Emma said: “What I say to people is how would you feel about organ ­donationyour child needed an organ  “If one of your loved ones needed a transplant, would you accept a donor organ  I think that is the best way of looking at it…you would take one, you should be prepared to give.”  Civil servant Paul added: “Max has never forgotten the children on the ward who did not make it. “He remembered them when we decided to join the Mirror campaign almost exactly three years ago. And he still remembers them now.” Max, who has a -year-old brother, Harry, has formed an unbreakable bond with Loanna and Joe and their ­children Bradley, , Katelyn, , and -year-old Keely – who he calls his “second family”. Both the Johnsons and Balls paid tribute to Mirror readers, who backed our campaign to reform the organ law – which now assumes everyone is a donor unless they opt out.  Experts believe it will give surgeons  more organs to ­transplant ­annually, saving hundreds of lives each year. Thousands signed up to join the organ donor register, and petition Parliament for change. It was backed by footballer Andy Cole – who received a kidney from his nephew Alexander Palmer – surgeon Sir Magdi Yacoub, The British Heart Foundation, Kidney Care UK, the British Medical Association and Kaylee Davidson-Olley, the first successful and longest surviving baby transplant in Europe after receiving her heart at just five months old. NHS Blood and Transplant had a huge rise in the number of donors signing up. Its medical director for organ ­donation, John Forsythe, said: “As the situation with Covid- is ever changing, so is the picture regarding donation and transplantation. “Some units have made the dficult decision to close their transplant programmes for now. This to support the NHS in treating Covid- patients.  “Lesaving transplants are still going ahead as long as clinical staff feel it is safe. Transplant teams will talk to patients and balance their need against the additional challenges of being immunosuppressed at this time and the challenges being faced within the NHS at this moment.” Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: “Coronavirus has vividly reminded us that le is a precious gt, one that we must do all we can to treasure and protect. “It’s why the new organ donor opt-out law, which comes into force today, is so important.” How Mirror helped bring in donor law April  Teddy Houlston became Britain’s youngest donor, donating his organs after dying aged just  minutes. It led to more than , people signing the organ donor register.  December  The soft opt-out system comes into force in Wales after a  law change. The Daily Mirror launches its Change the Law for Le campaign calling for legislation change in England too.  July  Labour MP Geoffrey Robinson came up in the Private Members’ Ballot and chose to use it to change the law to presumed consent in England.  September  We revealed that  Brits could have been saved that yearan opt-out system had been in place.  October  Prime Minister Theresa May gave the bill government backing.  February  The bill finally becomes law after passing its final hurdle in the House of Lords. A huge public information campaign begins to let people know thatthey do not opt out, it is assumed that they consent to donate. May  The law comes in to force. Transplants up after Covid- shutdown By Health Editor Martin Bagot Lesaving transplants are being ramped up again as Max and Keira’s Law comes in to force on Wednesday. Most operations had been delayed due to fears vulnerable patients might contract Covid- during surgery. And health minister Lord Bethell has said that while NHS bosses had no choice but to impose the policy many organs had been “wasted” as a result. Care minister Helen Whately told the Commons yesterday “over , people in England are waiting for a transplant”. She said: “During the peak of the pandemic, there were many days that there were no transplants. “As of last week there have been  referrals,  donors and  transplants. “We have a duty now more than ever to push ahead with measures that will reduce human suffering and help people improve their quality of le. “That is exactly what this law does.” The law presumes all adults in England agree to be donors unless they opt out. Anthony Clarkson, of NHS Blood and Transplant, said: “We hope this will prompt all of us to consider whether or not we want to donate our organs.” Fiona Loud, of Kidney Care UK, said it “gives a shining light of hope” to the hundreds needing a kidney transplant. “Capacity and resource must be built back up so that precious organs do not go to waste.”  aposHave that conversation for kids like my Ethanapos By Julie McCaffrey and Grace Macaskill All day and night, Roseleila Eaves has her phone on full charge, the ringtone set to loud and always within easy reach. Becausea call comes to say a donor heart has become available, -month-old son Ethan’s le depends on it. The tot has been in Great Ormond Street Hospital since August last year and is hooked up to an articial heart. All he knows is that the cannulas get in the way of his crawling practice. He is blissfully unaware they are keeping him alive until a tiny heart transplant takes place. His family, who have been warned the coronavirus outbreak means longer waits for transplant ops, are appealing for parents to talk about donation should the worst happen.  Roseleila, , from Luton, says: “I can only imagine how raw and devastating a conversation about organ donation could be when a parent has just lost a child. “But NHS studies have found many parents have said in hindsight they would have agreed. “Many young lives would be savedthose conversations were had now. Talk to each other and talk to your childrenthey’re old enough, so you know their wishes. Today, the day Max and Keira’s Law comes into force, marks  days since Ethan’s been on the urgent transplant list.” Ethan was diagnosed with an enlarged heart in August , seven months after engineer dad Richard, , had a transplant for a dferent heart condition. He was born a healthy lb oz and when sent for a routine heart test because of his family background was given the all clear. But on the couple’s first wedding anniversary on August , Ethan was rushed to hospital after falling ill and an X-ray found his heart was enlarged. In a -hour op, Ethan was wired to a mechanical heart after his own began beating dangerously fast.  “Sadly, it’s not a cure and comes with a risk of blood clots,” says Roseleila. “He desperately needs the transplant. Every night when I leave him in hospital tohome to my husband and two older children, I become emotional and so does Ethan.” Max and Keira’s Law does not apply to under-s and parents still have to give permission for doctors to use their organs. Before the pandemic, children waited an average  days for a transplant – compared with  for adults. More than  kids in the UK need an organ transplant and  of them are waiting for a heart. The size of the heart is important, meaning a donor of a similar size is needed. A young donor is their only hope. But for some, the call never comes. Amelia Brown has been waiting for a new kidney since she was born eight years ago. She has serious renal problems caused by vacterl syndrome. A transplant is her only hope of enjoying simple childhood joys. Mum Gemma, , of Sheffield, says: “Amelia stays positive by saying things like, ‘When I get a new kidney I’ll be able to jump really high’. “She stays cheerful and positive and that helps me and my husband, Jason. The idea of the transplant never happening is unthinkable. “That’s why we urge families to have the conversation about organ donation. People often avoid them because it’s too awful to think about.But for many parents of children on the transplant list, that’s the reality.Follow Ethan’s journey on Instagram at @ethaneaves_ Campaigneraposs perfect birthday gt By Warren Manger Max and Keira’s law is the birthday present Christine Cox has dreamed of for  years. Christine,  today, began campaigning to change the law after her brother Peter died of a brain tumour in  aged .

Research by Loughborough University sheds light on the shameful crisis, with . million children estimated to be in poverty across the UK. The horrying data found the poverty rate has risen fastest in the North East, and where it now affects nearly a quarter of children. Horried MPs in the region have voiced their anger at the government for failing families in their constituencies. Heaviest hit has been Middlesbrough, where more than four in  children are classed as being below the breadline, even before housing costs are taken into account. And he continued: “Austerity has hit places like Middlesbrough hardest. Even the Tories have woken up to the lack of fairness revealed by glaring regional inequalities but its they who have made it increasingly worse ever since they came back into power.And he warned that unless the government properly supports struggling families, it will get a great deal worse. Find out how bad child poverty is in your community by entering your postcode here: Mr McDonald said: It was bad enough before the Covid crisis but the pandemic not only exposes all of that, it will in all likelihood makes things a lot worse. Labour MP Chi Onwurah, who represents Newcastle Central, toldshe is horried, but not surprised at the figures. The analysis shows that the child poverty rate has risen from .% to .% - the third highest increase in Britain. She said: Whataposs horrying is that weaposre the sixth richest nation in the world, and yet this is happening. A signicant proportion of children in poverty have at least one parent in work, so what the last  years of austerity have done is shown that work doesnapost pay anymore.  Ms Onwurah said that the coronavirus pandemic is making the situation even more desperate for struggling families. She said: My casework has gone up hugely since the coronavirus outbreak, there are a lot of people who have lost their jobs, or theyaposre carers for family members and are scared to go out. Weaposve had a huge surge in food bank useage. My concern is that we wonapost now see rises in the jobs that people need, and there wonapost be enough training and support to get them into work.She said many of her constituents have not had a pay rise since , and a five-week wait for Universal Credit is pushing many into poverty. Figures from the Department for Work and Pensions reveal that . million children were living in poverty in Great Britain in March last year.And the picture is even more bleak after housing costs are taken into account, with the figure rising to . million in the UK under the Tories - , more than a decade ago.North East - up to .% from .% - a .% rise  West Midlands - up to .% from .% - a .% rise  North West - up to % from .% - a .% rise  Yorkshire and Humberside - up to .% from .% - a .% rise  Scotland - up to .% from .% - a .% increase  London - up to .% from .% - a .% increase  South East - up to .% from .% - a .% increase  East of England - up to .% from .% - a .% increase  East Midlands - stayed the same, at .%  Wales - down to .% from .% - a .% decrease  South West - down to .% from % - a .% decrease Campaigners warn that unless the government takes steps to ease the burden on families, the coronavirus pandemic will make the situation even worse.The Daily Mirror is running a Give Me Five campaign - calling on Boris Johnson to urgently address the unfolding tragedy across Britain.We initially called for child benefit to be hiked by £ a week - but our charity partners now say the effect of the pandemic is so bad that the government needs to bring in a £ increase instead. The West Midlands saw child poverty levels rise from .% to .%, while the North West went from .% to %. However the proportion stayed the same in the East Midlands, at .%. And it fell slightly in Wales and the South West, the figures show.  Anna Feuchtwang, chief executive of the National Childrenaposs Bureau, who chairs the End Child Poverty group, said: We may all be experiencing the storm of Coronavirus together, but we are not all in the same boat. The government’s data shows the extent to which over the past four years, children in low income families have been cut adrt and are already experiencing unacceptable hardship through cuts and freezes to the benefits system. Our country’s children are now at severe risk of being swept deeper into poverty as a result of the pandemic and lockdown. This is why we are asking the government to strengthen the social security system which is there to hold us steady during tough times, by immediately increasing household income for those least well-off. The charity says an increase of at least £ per child per week to the child element of Universal Credit and Child Tax Credits would go a long way to covering the increased costs posed by the current and potential subsequent lockdowns. Her Majestyaposs net worth in  was said to be £million - but extensive repairs to Buckingham Palace are reported to have taken their toll on her funds, OK reports.The -year-old monarch currently ranks at  on the rich list and is estimated to be worth £million as of this year.It comes after reports royal residences will remain closed to tourists during the  coronavirus crisis and members of staff face pay freezes.For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE.    While The Queen herself is set to withdraw from public duties for months in the longest enforced absence ever during her reign.It was last week confirmed Buckingham Palace would remain shut to visitors for the remainder of the year, while those who have booked to explore the Queenaposs London home will be refunded. While the Royal Collection Trust has also ordered Frogmore House in Windsor and the Prince of Walesaposs London base Clarence House to remain closed in .  Garden parties and investitures at the Palace have already been cancelled, Trooping the Colour will not take place in its normal form and the royals have swapped public appearances for video calls as they carry out their duties while working from home. The Trust, which oversees tourism at royal residences, pays a £ million facility fee to the Royal Household for the privilege of bringing in visitors and a big chunk of it, although not all of it, will be lost. That fee bolsters the £. million the Queen currently receives from the taxpayer under the Sovereign Grant, which is equivalent to  per cent of the Crown Estate profits. The Sun reported Lord Chamberlain Earl Peel - the most senior official of the royal household - has warned staff that income is expected to fall by a third this year leaving reported losses of £.m.In an email to staff seen by the newspaper, the Lord Chamberlain said the royal household was not immune to the impact of the pandemic. All but essential expenditure has been suspended, a recruitment freeze has been implemented and the annual pay review has been paused, he reportedly told staff. A Palace spokesman said the time to address this issue can only come when the impact of the crisis is clearer. At the moment the attention of the royal household is on ensuring it follows all the guidelines and supports the national effort in combatting Covid-, he added.However, it was reported last week Her Majesty had instructed a team of builders to resume work on the £ million refurbishment of Buckingham Palace now that the Government has eased lockdown measures. The Queen has been staying at Windsor Castle with the Duke of Edinburgh and is expected to remain there for the foreseeable future. Between July and September, while the Queen is usually away at Balmoral, thousands of tourists descend on the Palace for the annual opening of its state rooms to the public. It is believed to be the first time it will be staying shut during the summer months since it first opened its doors in .

title: summer camping holidays could campsites
story: NewsBrits could enjoy summer camping holidays with sites set to reopen in JulyWork and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey said campsites are eager to reopen this summer as Brits face not being able to travel abroad, with some possibly reopening in JulyShareCommentsByJamie Hawkins:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsCampsites could reopen in July " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCampsites could be allowed to open this summer, a senior government minister has said.The coronavirus pandemic has left it increasingly unlikely Brits will be able to holiday abroad this summer, with countries still imposing strict lockdowns.However, camping holidays could be allowed to go ahead, with some sites possibly opening in July. Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey told Sky: I know there are a lot of campsites that are very keen for people to come.  Some of this is being carefully considered, recognising that we have a reduced outdoor transmission risk, that things like camping may well become suitable. But that is a decision that still needs to be taken for later this year, potentially in July or even later in the year, recognising that we need to do all we can to keep that R rate below one, the number of infections down, and we need to be careful when we take those steps. Caravan sites are also hoping to open to the public this summer. Holiday companies, such as Haven holiday par,k have revealed ways that they would reopen.  Currently all of the chainaposs  parks remain closed until July . However, staff are working towards welcoming guests back when it is safe to do so whilst ensuring they comply with the coronavirus restrictions. If youaposre planning on booking a holiday with Haven when they reopen then you sadly wonapost be able to use the swimming pool, enjoy activities, entertainment or eat in the pubs and restaurants. But you will be able to book a holiday home, order takeaway food and use the open beaches.  Itaposs all part of the aposHaven Hideawayapos which aims at still giving families a much needed break while following social distancing rules. The company says that prices for these holidays have been adjusted to reflect the experience and guests who already have breaks booked during this period will not be affected at this stage. Gerard Tempest, guest and proposition director, said: “We have thousands of guests who have already had breaks cancelled this year due to the coronavirus pandemic.  “We look forward to reopening our parks as soon as government advice allows and as soon it is safe to do so, and are busy making changes to the way we operate our parks to ensure we can comply with the latest requirements. With social distancing requirements likely to remain in place, we don’t expect to be able to provide the full Haven experience to the number of guests we would normally welcome.

story: NewsLockdown exercises to beat diabetes during coronavirus pandemicIf you have diabetes type  or prediabetes, regular exercise is crucial to improve your blood sugar controlShareCommentsByClare Fitzsimons:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPeople with diabetes during this time need to take extra care " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDespite the recent relaxing of lockdown rules,​ staying active remains tougher than ever, with gyms and swimming pools still closed. However,you have diabetes type  or prediabetes, regular exercise is crucial to improve your blood sugar control. Getting fit will also reduce your risk of suffering from further complications such as heart disease and stroke. But you don’t have to become a marathon runner overnight – or indeed start any form of extreme workout. Instead, just increasing your activity levels by a moderate amount can make a huge dference. Always consult your doctor before starting any new exercise plan, especiallyyou have diabetes or any other underlying conditions. How does exercise help with diabetes  When you move about more, your muscles work harder, which means they use up more of their favourite fuel – glucose . Because exercising requires your muscles to burn off excess glucose for energy, it lowers your all-important blood sugar levels. Dr Sarah Brewer says: “Exercise is incredibly important for diabetic patients. It lowers blood sugar and stress levels, which make it helpful in both preventing the disease and controlling it.” How much is enough  People with diabetes type  or prediabetes should get the same recommended  minutes of moderate exercise a week as the rest of us – but should take care not to miss more than two days of exercise in a row to maintain a healthy weight and steady blood sugar. In other words, about  minutes of exercise, five days a week. Aerobic activity at moderate intensity basically means exercising at a level that raises your heart rate and gets you a little bit out of breath. This can include outdoor pursuits such as brisk walking, gentle jogging, bike riding, tennis and golf – all of which are now allowed. Break it up To make the -minute weekly target even more achievable, your daily exercise quota can be broken up into -minute chunks throughout the day, so it’s easier to fit in. With a bit of imagination, most days in lockdown are full of opportunities to get your body moving. Pick and mix from the following activities to help make up your  minutes of exercise, five days a week target. Move to the beat Play your favourite music loud and get moving at home. Dancing is one of the best forms of exercise and is great for losing weight, improving posture, boosting mood and beating stress. Just  minutes of jiving can burn nearly  calories. And the more energetic your moves are the better.  A good clean win Spending so much time at home can mean we have to clean the house more than ever, so why not put in a bit of added elbow grease and make it count as exercise  For example, mopping the floor for  minutes burns  calories, while vigorous vacuuming can burn  calories an hour. The bonus is you’ll be left with a gleaming house! Get the garden sorted Gardening is great exercise that you don’t even realise you’re doing on a nice day outside. Researchers at Kansas State University found it could help strengthen your limbs, boost your heart health and encourage flexibility. And just half an hour of proper digging will burn up to  calories! So get weeding, pruning and mow that early summer lawn. You could even boost your diet and save cash by growing your own veg. Spending time in the garden also has the added bonus of boosting your levels of Vitamin D – the immune-boosting nutrient made by sunlight on skin - which can become deficientwe spend long periods indoors. Workout in your home office It’s amazing how many calories you can burn while sat down – just by moving your limbs a bit more. If you’re at a home desk, try marching your feet up and down on the spot for a few minutes – this will work the large muscles in your legs. For easy calf exercises, simply raise your feet up on the toes and lower them. And to tone your tummy, sit up straight and pull your stomach muscles in towards your spine. Keep breathing normally and hold this position for  seconds. Count your steps Hit the well-known , steps a day target for a full week and you will have done roughly the same level of activity as the recommended  weekly minutes of exercise. However, even with the more relaxed lockdown, we’re all typically walking less at the moment. Soyou have a pedometer, a fitness tracker or even an iPhone, which all have built-in activity monitors, carry it at all times to check you’re achieving the target number of steps each day. A few steps short today  Use the extra daylight to head outside for a brisk evening walk. Lt some beans You can exercise without any equipment at all – saving the cost of buying expensive gym kit. For example, why not use a couple of cans of baked beans to strengthen your arms  Simply hold your “weights” down by your sides with your palms facing forwards. Then, without moving the upper part of your arms, slowly bend your arm at the elbow, bringing the cans up to your shoulders. Return to the starting position, keeping each movement slow. Repeat - times per arm.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA medical student who makes £, a month selling photos of her feet online says she devotes six to  hours a day making them look aesthetically pleasing. Using the working name Sweet Arches, the -year-old is funding her studies with her unusual sideline job, but warns itaposs far from an easy way to make a quick buck. Admitting to having a food fetish herself, Sweet gets up to  messages a day with unusual photo requests. She said: “Some people like the soles of the feet, some like the toes, some like to see them in dferent positions. “People like to watch me crush things, like raspberries, grapes or cakes with my toes. I’ve actually had someone ask me to squish ants, but that’s a no no for me. Anything that’s living, I won’t do that! “The strangest request was from someone asking me to run him over in my car! I said absolutely not. That’s definitely the craziest thing I’ve refused to do. Working in a hospital, I thought that would be quite counter-productive! “Some fans like ‘self-foot worship,’ where I play with my feet on camera. Others ask me to suck, kiss or lick my toes, or ask for me to send them worn boots or shoes. “One client asked for a pair of my boots. A lot of people with a foot fetish like the stinky smell, but it’s super hard for me to get my feet to stink. The client was still happy though, even though they smelled like my coconut foot mask!  Sweet, who lives in Portland in Oregon, US, also works in a hospital theatre, but earns a lot more with her foot work - often up to £, a year. “After one month of doing this, I tripled my hospital income as a surgical assistant - which is ,before tax. It’s insane. “Having a foot fetish myself, I started doing it for fun a year ago, just to share pictures of my cute feet. I didn’t think I could make a living from it.” Sweet Arches says she has been fascinated by her own and other peopleaposs feet since childhood.  “I have always had a foot fetish, enjoying pedicures and making sure my feet look good,” she recalled. “Even when I was very young, Iaposd always compliment people on their feet or randomly give foot massages to my friends, whereas most people think feet are weird. They would call me gross. “Then, about two years ago, a friend showed me that there was a whole community of others like me online, so I ed right in. I was so happy to find like-minded people.“I set up my own page on Instagram in May  and started posting pictures and videos every day. I had no idea what I was doing, but looked at other sites for inspiration, then a few bigger pages gave me a shout out, so my followers went up.“Now I have , followers on Instagram and , on Twitter.”Sweet now also has an OnlyFans account - a website which allows users to pay a subscription for exclusive content. “I direct everybody to my OnlyFans site, so they can request videos or pictures,” she said. “I’m still on a learning curve with it all. Some girls will offer pornographic videos or pictures, but I do not do that. “There’s all kinds of dferent stuff and you can make it your own.” As well as fans paying monthly subscriptions and buying inidual videos or custom content, Sweet Arches receives tips in the form of gts and recently enjoyed a day out at a spa.  She keeps custom videos to a minimum, so she has time to keep on top of requests and messages. She said: “I now have almost , subscribers on Only Fans, and usually get  to  messages or requests a day, so it is a lot to get through -  although I have a friend who used to be a porn star, who gets more than ,. “Mine are mostly to do with feet, but there are requests for other pictures. “I never get fully naked. I do respond to some risqué requests, but Iaposm cautious. “Everybody is super respectful, though. Eventhey are asking me for something and I tell them I’m not willing to do it, they are still really polite. “But I do get sent, shall we say, pictures of male anatomy. That is a hazard of the job!” Keeping her fans happy means Sweet Arches ensuring that her feet are always in tip top condition.  “I do my own pedicures and manicures twice a month, she said. Often I will go for natural or nude nail colours, but I will also take requests from people. “I love a foot mask, too, and have a double-sided pumice stone in the shower that I use every day. “I thinksomeone takes care of their feet, the rest of their body will look good. She said: “I feel in control of my body and I can say yes or no to requests. I’m so passionate about it and have so much respect for the foot fetish community.” But she does receive some negative messages about her fetish work. “Most of the messages I get are really nice, but I will get the odd vomit emoji, she said. The most negative thing I’ve heard is that I’m fat or a chubby girl – and that doesn’t bother me at all. “I’m so thankful that I’ve been able to make an income from this and that I can pay for my studies. My ultimate goal is to be able to help my mum to retire. She is in remission from cancer and has been continuing to work as an auditor and quality line leader through her recovery. She is a power house and Iaposd love to be able to help her.” But, with unemployment rising due to the Covid- pandemic, Sweet Arches is cautioning against people thinking that selling pictures of their feet is a quick way to make money. “It takes time and commitment to get to where I am now and you do have to have aesthetically pleasing feet, like I do,” she said.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Two more Chinese cities have been sealed off after new coronavirus cases were reported.The cities of Jilin and Shulan, both in the province of Jilin in northwestern China, have seen a worrying spike of Covid- infections. Jilin, home to around . million, has sealed off one of its districts this week after changing the areaaposs emergency level to aposhigh-riskapos. Today, the city reported a total of  new infections, and  in Shulan, which has a population of ,. The  new cases are believed to be linked to the same source, as officials investigate how the first person caught Covid-. According to Chinese media six officials from both cities have been removed from their pots following the new cluster of cases. New measures in the province of Jilin have seen trains and buses have been cut off, schools shut, and thousands being put into strict lockdown. Chinese people in the area have expressed their frustration at the new measures which have quashed hopes that le could soonto normal. “Everyone is jittery,” said Wang Yuemei, a pharmaceutical factory worker in neighboring Tonghua, told  Bloomberg News.“I never ever expected Jilin province to be a hard-hit area when the whole country is getting back to normal now.” Shulan went into lockdown last week quarantined some , people in a failed bid to contain the second outbreak. Fengman District has recorded  cases of local infection in the same period and was put on lockdown on Monday after a -point directive from the local health commission. The travel restrictions include bans on all outbound foot and vehicle traffic, as well as the closure of schools and entertainment venues such as cinemas, gyms and restaurants. Residential districts have been put on closed management, with each household allowed to send one member to shop for essentials once a day. All shops and the majority of supermarkets in the districts also shut on Monday, reports added, while city officials were also gathering testing kits and protective equipment for health workers. Images show shutter doors closed and streets barricaded and nearing empty as the restrictions came into place at the weekend.  Following an order on May , the Jilin Ice Sports Center was converted into a field hospital in  hours and is now ready to accept patients. It was still unclear which category of patients would be sent to the winter sports arena. Last week, footage also showed secondary school pupils being sent home as case numbers grew. Classes had only just resumed on April  after much of China declared victory of the coronavirus outbreak. It comes as the city of Wuhan ordered all  million residents to be tested for coronavirus.  Dubbed the ‘-day battle’, the Chinese city officials launched a campaign on Thursday, May , after the Wuhan Health Commission announced a cluster of six new infections - the first since the city ended its two-month lockdown on Wednesday, April . Authorities have said the ambitious plan may be the only way to identy all asymptomatic carriers in the city, where residents remain wary and concerned about a second wave of infections.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA nurse treating coronavirus patients has been photographed wearing just lingerie under her transparent PPE. The unnamed Russian woman was working on a Covid- ward, treating only male patients, a a hospital in Tula. The image quickly went viral, as she can be seen wearing matching black bra and knickers as she writes a patientaposs chart. But hospital chiefs were not amused and punished the nurse for “non-compliance with the requirements for medical clothing”. The nurse, in her s said she was “too hot” wearing her nurses’ unorm under the gown.She told her managers at Tula Regional Clinical Hospital that she did not realise the PPE she wore when treating coronavirus patients was so transparent.The regional health ministry reported that “a disciplinary sanction was applied to the nurse of the infectious diseases department who violatedrequirements”. Her chiefs at first said the woman was wearing “lingerie” but later claimed she had a “swimming suit” beneath the gown. The nurse has not spoken publicly on the incident and the exact details of the disciplinary action were not revealed. One patient said there was no objection from men in the coronavirus ward while admitting there was some embarrassment. A reader of local newspaper Tula News congratulated the nurse. “At least someone has a sense of humour in this gloomy, gloomy reality,” said Sergey Ratnikov. “Why the reprimand ” asked Albert Kuzminov. Another supporter said: “Everyone shouted at her, but no one paid attention that she was dressed in this way because of the heat. “Maybe you need to yell at the management … because there is no normal air conditioning here.” Marina Astakhova posted: Well done, she raised the mood of the patients.” While Valery Kapnin wrote: “Why punish the nurse, you need to reward her. “Seeing this outfit, no-one wants to die.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Sheaposs the princess who has bravely swapped her royal duties for le on the health service frontline to help care for coronavirus patients.Princess Sofia of Sweden, who is married to the eldest son of King Carl XVI Gustaf, made the courageous decision to become a medical assistant in the Sophiahemmet hospital. She had to take part in a training scheme at a Stockholm university before taking up the role and cutting back on her royal duties so she can help the very sickest in hospital. The princess shared a photo of her wearing full scrubs on social media and has been widely praised for stepping up to help during the coronavirus pandemic. The snap shows her name badge, which simply says aposSofiaapos. A statement from the Swedish Royal Family said: In the crisis we find ourselves in, the Princess wants to get involved and make a contribution as a voluntary worker to relieve the large workload of health care professionals. Her role means she will be cleaning, helping with patient care and assisting in the kitchens. The -year-old joined Swedenaposs royal family in  and she and her husband, Prince Carl Philip, have two children - but Princess Sofia is used to le in the limelight. Now a well-respected member of the royal family, Princess Sofia first found fame as a model when she was just . And when she and Prince Carl Philip began dating, eyebrows were certainly raised in royal circles over her past. Princess Sofia started her career in front of the camera as a glamour model, posing for Swedish lads mag, Slitz, in camouflage knickers with a snake draped around her shoulders - and not a lot . At the time the young model said she had taken the job to help her pay for college. But she was extremely popular with Slitz readers and in  was crowned Miss Slitz. From modelling it was only a small step into the world of reality TV. Princess Sofia starred in the show Paradise Hotel. It saw a group of beautul single people moved into a lavish hotel to see what happened. While she was a contestant on the show, the now royal was given a massage, with her topless, from a man also taking part. Her new found fame opened all sorts of doors for the young model and she travelled to Los Angeles, where she met porn str Jenna Jameson. Princess Sofia later told the magazine that had propelled her into the spotlight, Slitz, that she and Jenna had kissed. She added: We ended up at the same party as Jenna. She came up saying that I was one of the cutest girls she had seen and wanted me to come and sit with them. And it seemed like le on the other side of the Atlantic agreed with the budding model and TV star, who relocated to New York. Here, she lived with her best friend and seemed to throw herself into the party lestyle. Princess Sofia and her pal are said to be the authors of a secret blog, where they detailed all their exploits with the rich and famous, including Puff Daddy and Hollywood A-listers like Mark Wahlberg. One entry said: To be a woman in NY is an advantage. Don’t take this the wrong way, but here the men aim to please. But it was on a visit back to Sweden that Princess Sofiaaposs le was to change forever.  She was on a night out in her native Stockholm with her friends when she was introduced to Prince Carl Philip - and the rest seems to be fate. Less than  months later the couple were living together and the princess-in-waiting had ditched her old le. Instead, she was now focused on her charity work and her role within in the royal family grew. She was pictured at official royal events, like the christening of Crown Princess Victoria’s daughter and in , she was the centre of her very own fairytale when she and Prince Carl Philip married in a stunning ceremony.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIndia and Bangladesh are bracing for a super cyclone that threatens to claim lives, cause catastrophic flooding and destroy more than half a million homes.Amid fears of a humanitarian disaster, millions living in the path of Cyclone Amphan - the most powerful storm in  years - have been moved to higher ground, but the mass evacuation has been hampered by the coronavirus pandemic. The monster storm was churning through the Bay of Bengal and was due to make landfall on Wednesday afternoon local time in a region that is home to millions of vulnerable residents in low-lying flood-prone coastal areas and the worldaposs largest refugee camp. Officials said Amphan could wash away thousands of fragile huts or shelters and destroy crops as it batters parts of India and Bangladesh with mph winds equivalent to a category  hurricane, heavy rain, huge waves and a storm surge as high as a two-storey house. Are you in the path of Super Cyclone Amphan  Email webnews@mirror. The stormaposs cloud field is , miles long from tip to tail - that’s the equivalent of the distance from Lisbon to Warsaw, CNN reported. CNN meteorologist Pedram Javaheri said: A storm of this magnitude with the amount of rainfall and the storm surge on the coast could be catastrophic across this region of India and Bangladesh. Heavy rain and strong winds began lashing two eastern Indian states and parts of Bangladesh hours before the powerful cyclone was due to make landfall. As many as  million people could be exposed to tropical cyclone winds during the cyclone, the Pacic Disaster Center said.Rescue teams were evacuating millions of villagers to higher ground in an operation complicated by the coronavirus pandemic.Bangladeshaposs disaster management officials said they were working on a war footing to evacuate about two million people from coastal areas as Cyclone Amphan approached from the Bay of Bengal. Oxfam fears up . million people may be displaced and , homes could be destroyed. More than  Rohingya refugees living on flood-prone Bhasan Char island in the Bay of Bengal were moved to storm shelters. The members of the persecuted minority from Myanmar were sent to the island this month after being rescued from boats. The United Nations has called for the refugees to be moved to the mainland to join more than a million more who live in sprawling camps in the worldaposs largest refugee camp outside the town of Coxaposs Bazar.Although that settlement, the worldaposs largest refugee camp, is expected to escape the worst of the storm, the danger level has been raised to nine from six, signying a severe threat.The weather department in India said Amphan was likely to  weaken into an extreme severe cyclonic storm and cross the coast near West Bengal state or Bangladesh.It predicted a storm surge of up to ft that threatens to submerge many homes and farm land.Disaster management official SG Rau said: The cyclone could wash away thousands of huts and standing crops. An Indian federal home ministry official said West Bengal and neighbouring Odisha state were struggling to house thousands of evacuees as existing shelters were being used as coronavirus quarantine centres. Extra shelters were being prepared in wholesale markets and government buildings with allowances made for social distancing, while masks and scarves were being distributed among the villagers.  Police in West Bengal state, which is expected to be badly affected by the storm, said people were unwilling to go to the shelters because they were afraid of contracting Covid- and many were refusing to leave their livestock behind. A senior police official in Kolkata told Reuters: We have literally had to force people out of their homes, make them wear masks and put them in government buildings. Railway officials have erted trains away from the cycloneaposs path to protect thousands of migrant workers travelling to eastern states from the capital New Delhi where they had lost their jobs due to the coronavirus lockdown. Pankaj Anand, of the humanitarian group Oxfam in India, described Amphan as a crisis on top of a crisis, Al Jazeera reported. He said: Many of the cyclone evacuation shelters are already being used as coronavirus quarantine centres or housing migrants who have ed to their coastal communities because of lockdown. People are worried there wonapost be enough space in the shelters and that they might catch coronavirus in them.

title: almost 3400 people in dundee sign on for universal credit during coronavirus pandemic
story: The number of Dundonians claiming Universal Credit rose by a whopping % in the first month of the coronavirus pandemic.Statistics published by the Office for National Statistics, sourced from the Department for Work and Pensions, show , people registered for the benefit between March  and April .It is a huge increase on the period running from February to March, when  people signed on, and includes both jobseekers and those who claim Universal Credit but are unable to work.However, the vast majority of the new claimants are either required to look for work or are preparing to start a job.After moves to other JobCentres are taken into account, the total number of claimants on file at the Dundee JobCentre stands at ,, up , from , the previous month.Jane McEwen, service manager at Dundee#s JobCentre Plus, says she and her team are coping well with the additional demand and are doing their best to support those out of work.#There#s been a record increase in the volume of people making claims to Universal Credit, and we have focused on making sure people get paid their money,# she said.#We#ve closed the doors here but we#re phoning people and have a new callback system so we don#t have customers sitting on phones for hours on end waiting to get through, which has been very positive.#We#re hitting % payment accuracy so there aren#t issues down the line, and we#re now looking at contacting them to do customer care, giving them information about how to manage themselves.#Analysis conducted by research unit, Centre for Cities also showed that the City of Discovery had the second highest percentage change in Scotland relating to the number of new people claiming unemployment benefit # with only Glasgow registering a higher percentage change from the month of March.Despite the majority of employers in sectors such as leisure and hospitality closing their doors during the pandemic, Ms McEwen says opportunities are still out there for those who want to work.She added: #It#s quite surreal in the office # we normally have banks of desks together but we can#t do that at the moment due to social distancing. But we are still here to help.#Figures from the Citizen#s Advice Bureau in Dundee also show that he number of people in the city seeking advice on crisis grants has seen a sharp increase since the beginning of lockdown.Tracy McNally, director of the CAB Dundee, explained: #In March, one in  pieces of advice that we gave in relation to social security benefit was on crisis grants.#But in April, that rose to one in  which is a huge increase and I would say the reason for that is the basic need for money.#I would stress the importance of getting a benefit check to people. story: Andy Walker’s latest contribution to BwB states how amazing a simple question can cause ‘animosity’.He takes up the story: “I was recently at a junior match, standing among an array of veteran boys club former players of assorted ability.“This included the likes of Davie Bruce, Danny McAlpine and John Daley.“They all played at one time for Butterburn Youth Club.“I put the question to them: ‘Who was the first Butterburn player to play for Celtic FC ’“I produced a picture of Butterburn and told them he was in the photo.“After many mute moments, and a lot of shaking of heads, their squirming got the better of me.“A further clue was he played at least two games in Europe for the Celts, and maybe more, possibly five.“The half-time whistle at the junior game saved their bacon.“During the second half, I was approached by other unknown former Burn players asking for the name, and I said ‘You are standing beside him!’“It was Hamish McAlpine.”Andy further explained: “The situation arose, at the start of season of - when Celtic had a goalkeeping problem.“Packie Bonner, Allen McKnight and young prospect Andy Murdoch had long-term injuries, and the team were touring Austria and Czechoslovakia.“While there, they played two trialists – an U  keeper and an Austrian keeper.“However, both were considered not to be up to scratch.“An SOS was sent out and former Tannadice hero Hamish McAlpine responded.“He had just left United, so, really, it was a no-brainer.“I spoke to Hamish recently and he reckons it was five appearances.“Ultimately, it did not lead to anything long-term as Celtic signed Alan Rough and Ian Andrews.” vw, px"  This photo is from  and was a football match between local solicitors and the Dundee Constabulary. title: dundee united dundee fc craig conway kyle letheren salford
story: Dundee United hero Craig Conway and ex-Dundee keeper Kyle Letheren are free agents after leaving Salford City.Letheren, a Championship winner with the Dark Blues in , announced his departure from the high-profile League Two side co-owned by Manchester United’s Class of  legends including David Beckham, Gary Neville, Ryan Giggs and Paul Scholes on Twitter.He wrote: “I’d like to wish Salford City FC all the best for the future. Stop-start season but nothing but good things to say about the club. Looking forward to the next chapter.”Salford later confirmed Conway – whose Scottish Cup Final double for United against Ross County was ten years ago on Friday – was among  stars released by the Greater Manchester outfit managed by former Scotland full-back Graham Alexander.They said: “We would like to thank each and every player for their considerable efforts on behalf of the club and extend our sincere best wishes for the future.”Conway, , played  games for Salford in   after joining in October following five-and-a-half years at Blackburn Rovers.The winger, capped seven times for the national team, left the Tangerines for Cardf a year after his Hampden heroics.Last week he said: “It is so hard to put into words exactly how you felt but there was a massive sense of achievement.“The title: dundee united ian harkes grandfather coronavirus
story: He could hardly have been further away, but the coronavirus pandemic hit close to home for Dundee United midfielder Ian Harkes.His grandfather, Ron Kunihiro, had been fighting Covid- since early March with Harkes stuck in Dundee unable to catch a flight back to America.Thankfully, now at their family home in Virginia and by his side, Harkes has witnessed the -year-old recover.“I was just happy to get home. My granddad got out of the hospital and he’s been battling Covid,” the -year-old said.“He’s had it for a while. It’s been a long process which started back in the beginning of March when he first started to feel ill.“He went in to the hospital for  days or so. I was still in Dundee so we had to FaceTime or Zoom call the family to keep updated on everything.“Thankfully, we were able to find some flights and get back over.“He’s healthy now which is great. It’s been great to see him recover and nice to be here with the family.“The challenge now is getting back over to Scotland but, thankfully, I’ve got a UK passport so I should be OK!”Harkes travelled back to the states with fiancée and Celtic Women’s player Sarah Teegarden a few weeks back.Their wedding plans are on hold and the country is in disarray but Harkes insists it’s nice to spend precious time with his loved ones.He continued: “She was able to come back as well which is good.“It’s nice to spend time together but all our wedding plans will be pushed back now.“On the mental side being back with them all helps tremendously, missing them throughout the year.“They came over around Christmas time but seeing them again six months later has been big. It always gives me a lt.“It’s a bit dferent here than the UK. Some things don’t seem so shut down but that’s just America right now – we’re not quite sure what’s going on.“It’s quite crazy just now with the amount of cases and, unfortunately, the amount of deaths we’ve had in America.“I think the country’s a little bit all over the place, some places are opening up and some are closed, but right now we’re still in lockdown in Virginia.“All the states are dferent but it’s been OK here.“I’m not sure how long that will be but we need to be safe, especially with having that experience in my family.“I think we’ve all had a little bit of a dferent view towards it but we’ll see how it goes and hope for the best.“We can still exercise and things like that. I’ve had space to go and run and cycle, do some things in the yard and touch a ball every day.“It’s been good to have certain resources back home and to keep doing stuff.”Like most, lockdown has been a test for Harkes’ mentally and physically. For him, it’s a challenge he soon hopes to rise to on the pitch.Harkes added: “It’s definitely been a challenge on both sides but, thankfully, the club provided us with a great fitness programme before we went on furlough to keep us ticking over.“I’ve been active and all of us want to be flying when we finally get the go-ahead to get back to playing.“We’re all trying to push each other and push ourselves.“On the mental side, the way we ended was a little tough because we wanted to play for the fans and finish out the season.“We really felt like we deserved the title and we knew it then but we just wanted to finish off the games and prove it to everyone.“We’ll have that desire to get back on the pitch and play hard when we finally get it going.”The United support have taken to Harkes since he joined the club in January last year, as much for his flowing locks as his skill on the pitch.He is pleased to inform them nothing has changed on the hair front in lockdown but that he might soon be forced to take matters into his own hands.“I’m still going strong but it will be cut before everything gets going again,” Harkes said.“I think it’s getting a bit ridiculous now.“I don’t want to start putting it up in a bun and everything.
