title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... who remain dear to them.ldquoTo ensure that this can continue, we ask all visitors to take good care of themselves and others by observing current health guidance, including social distancing.ldquoWe must also ask that the grounds are not used for exercise or dog walking.ldquoPlease help us look after the cemetery by taking any waste materials home.ldquoPlease note that the toilets remain after the Welsh Government introduced minor adjustments to the lockdown measures.The new rules allow people to exercise more than once a day near their home and enabled local authorities to begin the reopen from Tuesday, May , but by appointment only.The booking system is to help comply with social distancing regulations, protecting residents and staff.Residents will be able to book an appointment from am on Thursday, May  via the Vale councilrsquos website.There will be  slots released for the next fortnight of bookings, beginning May  -  slots at Atlantic Trading Estate and  for Llandow.Any resident undertaking a journey to a HWRC within the Vale must comply with the current Government guidance and adhere to the social distancing measures that are in place to ensure safe operation and use of the centres.To begin with, only cars will be permitted access to the HWRC on Atlantic Trading Estate, Barry, and at Llandow.It will not be possible to provide access or appointment for trailers or vans at this time.Due to current demand, initially the council will be only be issuing one appointment slot per household, per month until further notice.Residents are asked to only make a bookingit is absolutely necessary, due to the sitesrsquo reduced capacity, and to arrive no earlier than five minutes before their allocated time to avoid any unnecessary queuing.The guidelines state that before visiting, residents must sort their waste or recycling appropriately to minimise the time at the site and residents must provide proof of residency eg driving licence or utility bill and display this in their windscreen while waiting to enter the site.Residents must follow on-site safety signs and guidance and residents should only exit their car when advised to do so by a member of site staff.Staff will be unable to provide assistance with lting or sorting so it is important to ensure all waste and recycling is manageable.Residents are also reminded thatthey do not respect social distancing or are abusive to staff they will be asked to leave site.It is important to remember that fly-tipping is a crime and leaving items outside the gates of a HWRC, on the street or in parks, woodlands and fields may result in a fixed penalty notice of up to pound being issued or even prosecution.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Cllr Peter King said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank residents for the assistance they have provided by storing items they wish to dispose of until now.ldquoUnfortunately, the period during which our household waste recycling centres were closed means there is now a backlog to clear, which is why we need a strict booking system until demand s to normal.ldquoWe appreciate this may cause some inconvenience but Club, but instead she decided to use her skills to raise money for the charity - Annarsquos Rescue Centre, in Cardf, from where she got her cat, Rocky.Miss Dimech, , of Penarth, took portraits of families stood on their doorsteps locally as a personal project, on Friday May .And she hopes to stage an exhibition when conditions allow.She said: ldquoI had lost all motivation.ldquoMy camera had been sitting in a bag unused for eight weeks and I was getting far too used to sitting in my pyjamas all day.ldquoThe aim was to capture this strange moment in history and to be able to do what I love - get out and take photographs while following government guidelines.ldquoI havenrsquot been able to work since March and photography is a huge part of my lestyle and happiness.ldquoI have been able to create beautul memories for these families.ldquoBack in March our family adopted a beautul family cat, Rocky, from Annarsquos Rescue Centre in Rumney, she said. ldquoWe were amazed to discover how much work this charity was doing in rescuing, rehabilitating, caring for, and rehoming cats and kittens.ldquoI realised that I could use this opportunity to raise some money for the charity by combining my doorstep photography project as a fundraiser."Donations were not compulsory.ldquoDuring lockdown this money is very much needed to feed the surplus cats that currently canrsquot be rehomed due to vets not neutering at this time, but also to help towards any upkeep or vets bills.ldquoMyself and my partner visited  homes beginning at am and finishing at :pm.ldquoWe met some amazing families and thoroughly enjoyed our day out.ldquoWe have plans to attempt one more session in Dinas Powys, Sully, and Barry.She said: ldquoWhen I started the project I was worried that I wouldnrsquot find much to photograph and that it would be dficult to find inspiration on someonersquos doorstop.ldquoI was wrong.ldquoEach family has a very dferent dynamic and portrait photography is all about allowing dferent personalities shine through.ldquoThe images were intended to be natural, raw, and a reflection of the times and I feel that I have achieved that outcome with the help of those who took part.Miss Dimech and her partner allowed  minutes for each household.ldquoIt was amazing to meet so many new faces and to catch up with some of my previous clients," she said. ldquoEach household was extremely thankful and it was a blessing to have that social interaction that most of us have all been craving.ldquoWorking with people is what I do best.ldquoI am a chatterbox who thrives on social interaction.ldquoEach family had a dferent story to tell, some were still working, furloughed, bored or enjoying lockdown.ldquoI met animals, children, grandparents, parents, it was a great mix.ldquoMeeting new people and wielding a camera just makes my heart sing."I came home after a long day just bursting with excitement to start editing.ldquoOnce this is all over and the title: researchers identify security flaws contact tracing app
story: The issues have been flagged to the National Cyber Security Centre , which is involved in the apprsquos development, and it said it is in the process of fixing them.The researchers also warned legal protections around data use are needed in order to better protect personal privacy on the app, which is currently being trialled on the Isle of Wight.They say data associated with the app should be protected by legislation ldquofrom use by law enforcement, or any usage not directly related to Covid- prevention.Harriet Harman, chair of the Joint Committee on Human Rights, said on Tuesday that new laws to protect the privacy of personal information gathered by the app are a ldquono brainer.Ms Harman, who has prepared a Bill on the issue which is ready for introduction, said assurances by Health Secretary Matt Hancock do not provide any protection after he wrote to her saying the Government believes legislation is unnecessary because there is already the Data Protection Act.In their study of the contact tracing app, which was shared with the NCSC last week, security researchers Professor Vanessa Teague and Dr Chris Culnane identied a number of issues, including a weakness in the apprsquos registration process which could be exploited by hackers and used to manipulate data or create logs of fake contact events. vw,vw,px, px"It also highlighted a flaw which means storing unencrypted data on a userrsquos phone could potentially be used by law enforcement agencies to determine when two or more people met.The research added that generating new random ID codes for users once a day, rather than every  minutes like in other systems, makes it theoretically possible to determine intimate details about an app userrsquos lestyle, such as whether they ldquowoke up and went to bed with the same person, or more revealingly,they did not.Dr Ian Levy, technical director of the NCSC, thanked the researchers and confirmed the app development team is addressing all the issues raised.ldquoThe intent of being open before national launch was to show what the app will do, how it will do it, and to get some peer review from security and privacy researchers, he wrote in a blog post.ldquoThank-you to everyone whorsquos taken the time to look at the design and the beta code and provide us with useful feedback, whether thatrsquos directly, on GitHub or through the NCSCrsquos vulnerability disclosure programme.ldquoEverything reported to the team will be properly triaged .Dr Levy added the NCSC would not comment on specic legal issues raised by the researchers.In a further statement, a spokesman for the NCSC said: ldquoResponsible security researchers are an overwhelming force for good and their feedback was openly requested for the quickly developed beta app.ldquoIt was always hoped that measures such as releasing the code and explaining decisions behind the app would generate meaningful discussion with the security and privacy community.ldquoWe look forward to continuing to work with security and cryptography researchers to make the app the best it can be for the public..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Researchers title: stay alert slogan needs explanation admits minister
story: When announcing the lockdown on March , Downing Street introduced the slogan ldquoStay at home, which was well adhered to and praised for its clarity.But when Prime Minister Boris Johnson spoke on May  about easing the restrictions for England, new messaging urged the public to ldquostay alert to the virus, a slogan that has been criticised for being too vague.The devolved administrations refused to adopt the messaging at the same time and hit out at Mr Johnson for failing to consult them over the change.Additional advice has since started to appear, saying: ldquoKeep our distance, wash our hands, think of others and play our part. All together.Asked why the extra messaging was being introduced, Justice Secretary Robert Buckland said there is a need to explain the ldquodferent elements involved.He told Sky News: ldquoStay alert is very much still part of what it is all about.ldquoI think what wersquore trying to do is explain underneath that general direction what that means. vw,vw,px, px"Justice Secretary Robert Buckland said lsquomore nuancedrsquo messaging is involved in the lsquoStay alertrsquo slogan ldquoOf course the dferent elements to staying alert, which include washing hands, keeping our distance, builds up to that general approach which is that we all must be very much aware not only of each other but what we can do in order to minimise the inadvertent transmission of this terrible disease.The Cabinet minister said ldquostay alert is ldquomore dficult to explain than ldquostay at home because it involves ldquomore nuanced messages.ldquoI think lsquostay at homersquo had the clarity and simplicity of a direct instruction this was always going to be a more dficult moment when we had to give more nuanced messages and to encourage everybody to take those small steps out of the full lockdown, he added.ldquoIt is going to be a tough ask it is a very dficult time for everybody and the Government doesnrsquot pretend anything otherwise.ldquoWe have to keep developing those messages and thatrsquos why yoursquore hearing that kind of detail.Critics of the ldquostay alert message include Susan Michie, professor of health psychology and director of the Centre for Behaviour Change at University College London.Prof Michie is a member of the SPI subcommittee of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesndash the body that has been instrumental in guiding ministers through the coronavirus response ndash and said last week that the new direction is not clear enough.She said: ldquoI think the concern with the actual slogan ndash lsquostay alertrsquo ndash is itrsquos not very obvious what alert means, what people should be alert to, and what they should do , when being alert they identy something that isnrsquot defined..push,i[r].l*new title: council welcomes funding
story: Woman pushed into boot of car during ‘attempted abduction’Ambulance crews deal with two car crash on Armagh roadNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsCouncil welcomes fundingThe Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council has welcomed the Executive’s COVID- emergency funding for local councils.By The NewsroomTuesday, th May , : pm""This morningCommunities Minister, Deirdre Hargey, informed the Assembly that the Executive had agreed to provide a total of £. million to NorthernIreland’s  councils by way of an “immediate intervention”.Speaking after the announcement was made, ABC Lord Mayor, Councillor Mealla Campbell said: “As a Council it is our priority during this crisis to protect and ensure the delivery of our basic services but like many other councils at this time, the future of these essential services such as bin collections, burials and street cleansing are threatened by loss of income“I therefore welcome this announcement of funding, which will provide some interim assistance from now until the end of June.”Editorial Image. : Other rd PartyCommunities Minister, Deirdre Hargey MLA said: “Despite the current COVID- pandemic, councils continue to play an essential role in deliveringpublic services, such as waste collection and disposal, community support, and provision of registration and cemeteryservices.“The restrictions that have been introduced, with the clear purpose of protecting le and ensuring out health service has not been overwhelmed, have created a severe financial challenge for our  councils as they have lost practically all of their self-generated income through the closure of council facilities.“This funding will help assist councils with their cash flow and support them in the delivery of the vital services they are providing to the community at this time.“It will also help ensure that they are ready to play their key role in our post-pandemic recovery and limit the financial impact on ratepayers going forward.”While the additional funding is welcomed, Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council’s Lord Mayor said more will need to be done to ensure council’s can help communities to recover.“It is a first step but it is clear that further investment in local government will be required to ensure that Council are not only in a position to provide continuity of service to our ratepayers but that we are able to help our communities recover,” said the Lord Mayor.“The executive must look at longer term investment to support the financial resilience of our councils so that we are resourced to deliver on strategies for bespoke economic recovery and community support.“Councils will be in the frontline of transformation post COVID- and it is a priority that we are equipped to deal with the signicant body of work ahead.“Meanwhile a spokesperson for Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council said Council will continue to ensure vital public services are protected.“Council welcomes the announcement by Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey, and will continue to work with the Minister, and colleagues across councils, to make the case for support of local government to ensure vital public services are Removed    to cater for wrap advertlastScrollTop  stStatement issued by the four UK Chief Medical Officers Reporter: Ciara MaguireEmail: ciara.maguire@strabaneweeklyMonday  May  :A joint statement has just been issued from the four UK Chief Medical Officers on an update to coronavirus symptoms. “From today, all iniduals should self-isolatethey develop a new continuous cough or fever or anosmia. “Anosmia is the loss or a change in your normal sense of smell. It can also affect your sense of taste as the two are closely linked. “We have been closely monitoring the emerging data and evidence on COVID- and after thorough consideration, we are now confident enough to recommend this new measure. “The inidual’s household should also self-isolate for  days as per the current guidelines and the inidual should stay at home for seven days, or longerthey still have symptoms other than cough or loss of sense of smell or taste, they said. The statement is signed by Chief Medical Officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton, Chief Medical Officer for Northern Ireland, Dr Michael McBride, Chief Medical Officer for Scotland, Dr Gregor Smith and Chief Medical Officer for England, Professor Chris Whitty. Changes for the symptomatic inidual and their household: Iniduals will need to self-isolate immediatelythey develop a new continuous cough OR fever OR as of today, a loss or changed sense of normal smell or taste . All members of their household must also self-isolate according to current guidelines, unless the symptomatic inidual receives a negative test result.  addthis, Leave your commentTyrone Constitution- title: coronavirus morning update
story: NORTHERN Ireland Executive ministers and their officials have over the past  hours been involved in a number of initiatives and critical decisions relating to the Coronavirus emergency. A poundmillion rates relief package for business sectors hit hardest by the Covid- lockdown was announced by the Finance Minister Conor Murphy today. Building on the poundmillion scheme announced in March which gave all businesses a threemonth rates holiday, the new scheme will result in businesses in the following sectors being relieved of the obligation to pay rates for the full financial year up to  March : * hospitality, tourism and leisure* retail * childcare* Belfast City, Belfast International and City of Derry Airports. All businesses will also receive a one-month extension of the rates holiday up to  July . Minister Murphy confirmed: “The pandemic has had a devastating impact on the economy. The initial rates support package helped businesses with immediate cash-flow dficulties during the lockdown. As the Executive begins to ease the restrictions which have been necessary to save lives, I am pleased to announce this new scheme which importantly provides all businesses with an extended rates holiday for July. “Further support is then targeted at the sectors which will be in greatest need in the months ahead. This includes retail, hospitality, tourism, leisure, childcare and airports. This rates package, which is aligned with the Executive’s pathway to recovery, brings the total support for businesses from rates relief and grants to almost poundmillion.” Education Minister Peter Weir welcomed the Executive’s approval of an income scheme to support substitute teachers who are unable to access secure work during the Covid- shutdown of schools. With many schools closed during the pandemic except those supervising vulnerable pupils and the children of key workers, eligible substitute teachers, who were engaged between  January  to  March , will have access to an income for the period April to June . An additional income through this scheme will top up their income to at least % of that earned in the period. Minister Weir acknowledged: “I am fully aware of the signicant impact this pandemic has had on our pupils, teaching and non-teaching staff. The issue of funding for substitute teachers, who are unable to work and therefore unable to be paid, is one that and I, and my Department, have been working hard to resolve. Today, I am pleased to announce that we will be introducing an income support scheme for substitute teachers through the Covid- Response fund. The estimated total cost of the scheme is around poundmillion. My Department will allocate up to poundmillion and the Executive has agreed to fund the remaining poundmillion. I would also like to thank the Finance Minister for his support in this matter. Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey announced the Executive had allocated an additional poundmillion to support the most vulnerable people in housing during the Covid- emergency. The Supporting People Programme provides housing support for approximately , vulnerable iniduals living independently including: homeless people, older people, young people, and people with physical disabilities, learning disabilities and mental health issues. The additional funds will help maintain Supporting People services, which are commissioned by the Housing Executive and delivered through the public and voluntary and community sectors. Minister Hargey explained: “The additional funding will be used to address signicant staff shortages in the immediate term and mounting pressure in this area,the number of Covid- cases continues to increase. The money will fund overtime costs for existing staff and the use of the bank or agency staffing that is necessaryservices are to be maintained. Extra cleaning is also required, and the matter of a sufficient and adequate supply of PPE is being addressed.  “These are unusual times which demand actions and solutions. This funding allocation represents our commitment to the vulnerable people in Supporting People schemes, and the staff providing support to them. We support them and we are working hard to ensure their safety and wellbeing.” The allocation was also welcomed by Health Minister Robin Swann who added: “It is well recognised that supported living services better enable people to live to their full potential and reduce the need for acute health and social care services. Their value in society cannot be underestimated. “Officials across both departments are in regular communication to identy and address Covid- priorities across our Supporting People schemes. As a result my Department has now extended Covid- testing to all staff and residents of Supporting People schemes as well as providing a temporary supply of Personal Protective Equipment.” It was revealed by Minister Hargey that local councils will also be given pound.million to alleviate financial pressures as a result of the Covid- restrictions. The funding will ensure councils can continue to provide essential services and support those in need. Minister Hargey said: “Despite the current Covid- pandemic, councils continue to play an essential role in delivering essential services such as waste collection and disposal, community support, and provision of registration and cemetery services. The restrictions that have been introduced, with the clear purpose of protecting le and ensuring our health service has not been overwhelmed, have created a severe financial challenge for our  councils as they have lost practically all of their self-generated income through the closure of council facilities. “This funding will help assist councils with their cash flow and support them in the delivery of the vital services they are providing to the community at this time but will also help ensure that they are ready to play their key role in our post-pandemic recovery and limit the financial impact on ratepayers going forward.” The Minister previously announced that councils here are eligible to apply to furlough staff through the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme. This will help ensure that the rights of workers are respected and jobs are protected. This scheme along with this additional funding are supporting councils through this period.  addthis, Leave your commentTyrone Constitution- High Street, OmaghBT BDTel:     , ,, , ,  .jsp, , ,   ,
